events.title: An Unlikely Alliance and a Winter Provision Plan
detailed_summary: A cat persuaded a mouse of her profound affection and friendship, which led to the mouse consenting to share a home with her.
The cat highlighted the importance of storing food for the upcoming winter to prevent starvation.
She also warned the mouse about the perils of venturing out independently, specifically mentioning the risk of traps.
Heeding this counsel, they jointly procured a pot of fat.
After careful consideration, the cat suggested hiding the pot of fat within the church, underneath the altar, believing this location would ensure its safety from theft.
They mutually agreed not to access the fat unless they faced a situation of genuine, dire need.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it.’

events.text_segment: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together. ‘But we must make a provision for winter, or else we shall suffer from hunger,’ said the cat; ‘and you, little mouse, cannot venture everywhere, or you will be caught in a trap some day.’ The good advice was followed, and a pot of fat was bought, but they did not know where to put it. At length, after much consideration, the cat said: ‘I know no place where it will be better stored up than in the church, for no one dares take anything away from there. We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together. The cat, being a very prudent animal, thought it necessary to lay up a store of food for the winter, and she gave the mouse to understand that if they were to live together they must both work and save. The mouse, who was very small and timid, was quite willing to do as the cat said, and so they set to work together to gather provisions. One day, as they were looking for a safe place to hide their store, the cat proposed that they should put it in the church, under the altar, for she was sure that no one would think of looking there. The mouse, who had never been inside a church before, was much impressed by this idea, and they carried their pot of fat there and buried it carefully. Then they made a solemn agreement that they would not touch the fat unless they were in real distress, and so they went home and lived happily together for some time.

events.title: The Cat's First Deception: "Top-Off" Christened
detailed_summary: The pot of fat was securely placed in the church, but the cat soon felt an intense desire for it.
The cat fabricated a story about her cousin having a new son and requiring her to act as godmother at the christening, describing the imaginary infant as white with brown spots.
She asked for permission to leave for the day, entrusting the mouse with household duties.
The mouse willingly agreed, expressing a hopeful wish that the cat would think of her if any delicious food was available, particularly mentioning a longing for sweet red christening wine.
The cat's entire account was untrue; she neither had a cousin nor had she received an invitation to be a godmother.
She proceeded directly to the church, stealthily approached the pot of fat, and licked off the entire top layer.
Subsequently, she strolled along the town's rooftops, basked in the sun, and savored the thought of the pot of fat, only returning to their shared home in the evening.
The mouse welcomed her back, naturally assuming she had enjoyed a delightful day.
When questioned about the baby's name, the cat nonchalantly stated, "Top off!"
The mouse considered the name quite strange and out of the ordinary, inquiring if such a name was customary in the cat's family.
The cat brushed off the mouse's apprehension, retorting that the name was no more peculiar than "Crumb-stealer," a name she attributed to the mouse's own godchildren.

events.text_segment: So the pot was placed in safety, but it was not long before the cat had a great yearning for it, and said to the mouse: ‘I want to tell you something, little mouse; my cousin has brought a little son into the world, and has asked me to be godmother; he is white with brown spots, and I am to hold him over the font at the christening. Let me go out today, and you look after the house by yourself.’ ‘Yes, yes,’ answered the mouse, ‘by all means go, and if you get anything very good to eat, think of me. I should like a drop of sweet red christening wine myself.’ All this, however, was untrue; the cat had no cousin, and had not been asked to be godmother. She went straight to the church, stole to the pot of fat, began to lick at it, and licked the top of the fat off. Then she took a walk upon the roofs of the town, looked out for opportunities, and then stretched herself in the sun, and licked her lips whenever she thought of the pot of fat, and not until it was evening did she return home. ‘Well, here you are again,’ said the mouse, ‘no doubt you have had a merry day.’ ‘All went off well,’ answered the cat. ‘What name did they give the child?’ ‘Top off!’ said the cat quite coolly. ‘Top off!’ cried the mouse, ‘that is a very odd and uncommon name, is it a usual one in your family?’ ‘What does that matter,’ said the cat, ‘it is no worse than Crumb-stealer, as your godchildren are called.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
So the pot was placed in safety, but it was not long before the cat had a great yearning for it, and said to the mouse: 'I want to tell you something, little mouse; my cousin has brought a little son into the world, and has asked me to be godmother; he is white with brown spots, and I am to hold him over the font at the christening.'

'Oh, how nice!' said the mouse. 'Then you must go, of course. I shall be very glad to stay at home and take care of everything. But if you should come across any nice food, or if they give you sweet red christening wine, do think of me, and perhaps you can bring me a little something.'

'Of course I will,' said the cat, and off she went. But it was all a lie; she had no cousin, and no baby, and no christening. She went straight to the church, and there she crept up to the pot of fat, and licked off the whole top.

Then she went strolling along the house-roofs, and lay in the sun, and thought of the pot of fat, and was very happy. In the evening she came home again, and the mouse welcomed her back, and thought she had had a lovely day.

'And what is the baby's name?' asked the mouse.

'Top off!' said the cat carelessly.

'That is a queer name,' said the mouse. 'Do you always have such names in your family?'

**Chapter Title:** *CAT AND MOUSE IN PARTNERSHIP*

The cat’s mouth soon began to water for some more licking. The scent of the remaining fat, still lingering in the air, was enough to stir her appetite once more. She sat for a moment, eyes fixed on the pot, as if weighing the morality of her next move. But the cat was not one to be deterred by guilt for long. "All good things go in threes," she mused aloud, as if the phrase itself justified her next action. With a flourish of her tail, she concocted a third invitation, this time to be a godmother to a new, supposedly miraculous birth.

She described the infant in great detail: a completely black creature with only the faintest hint of white on its paws. "Such a birth is a very infrequent event," she declared, her voice dripping with the weight of importance. The mouse, already unsettled by the names "Top-off" and "Half-done," now found herself even more disturbed. "Why must they all have such strange names?" she asked, her voice barely above a whisper.

The cat, unbothered by the mouse’s unease, dismissed it as the product of her "dark-grey fur coat and long tail," and her lack of experience with the outside world. "You just don’t understand," she said, her tone both condescending and affectionate. "You’ve been cooped up too long."

While the cat was away, the mouse took it upon herself to tidy their home. She dusted the furniture, straightened the crooked picture frames, and even polished the floor until it gleamed. It was a small comfort in a world that had grown increasingly strange. Meanwhile, the cat, driven by her insatiable hunger, returned home late in the evening, her belly full and her heart light. "Everything is eaten up," she whispered to herself, as if it were a mantra of peace.

The mouse, upon seeing her return, immediately asked, "What is the name of the third child?" The cat, with a sly smile, replied, "All-gone." The mouse’s eyes widened in alarm. "All-gone?" she repeated, her voice trembling. "I have never seen that name in writing. What does it mean?" She curled up in a tight ball, her mind racing with possibilities, and fell into a restless sleep, her dreams filled with shadows and strange names.

---

**End of Segment**

events.title: The Truth Revealed and the Mouse's Demise
detailed_summary: Following these events, the cat received no more (fabricated) invitations to be a godmother.
When winter arrived and external food sources disappeared, the mouse recalled their carefully stored provision.
She cheerfully proposed to the cat that they retrieve their pot of fat and enjoy its contents.
The cat replied with a biting sarcasm, suggesting the mouse would derive as much pleasure from it as she would from sticking her tongue out the window, implying there would be nothing to enjoy.
They journeyed to the church, and although the pot of fat was still in its designated spot, it was completely empty.
The mouse, aghast, exclaimed that she now understood the situation and that the cat's duplicity had come to light.
She accused the cat of having consumed all the fat during her supposed godmother excursions, beginning to recount the deceptive names: "First top off, then half-done, then—".
The cat furiously cut her off, threatening to devour the mouse as well if she uttered another word.
The name "All-gone" was already on the unfortunate mouse's lips; the moment she spoke it, the cat leaped upon her, captured her, and consumed her.
The narrator concludes with the somber reflection that this, indeed, reflects the nature of the world.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Verily, that is the way of the world.

events.text_segment: From this time forth no one invited the cat to be godmother, but when the winter had come and there was no longer anything to be found outside, the mouse thought of their provision, and said: ‘Come, cat, we will go to our pot of fat which we have stored up for ourselves—we shall enjoy that.’ ‘Yes,’ answered the cat, ‘you will enjoy it as much as you would enjoy sticking that dainty tongue of yours out of the window.’ They set out on their way, but when they arrived, the pot of fat certainly was still in its place, but it was empty. ‘Alas!’ said the mouse, ‘now I see what has happened, now it comes to light! You are a true friend! You have devoured all when you were standing godmother. First top off, then half-done, then—’ ‘Will you hold your tongue,’ cried the cat, ‘one word more, and I will eat you too.’ ‘All-gone’ was already on the poor mouse’s lips; scarcely had she spoken it before the cat sprang on her, seized her, and swallowed her down. Verily, that is the way of the world.

events.title: The Princess's Royal Upbringing and Journey Preparations with a Fairy's Gift
detailed_summary: Following the king's demise, the queen devotedly raised their exceptionally beautiful daughter, aided by a benevolent fairy.
When the princess reached adulthood, she was betrothed to a prince from a distant land.

As the time for her marriage and departure neared, the queen meticulously assembled a vast collection of costly items suitable for a royal bride, including jewels, precious metals, trinkets, and fine garments.
The queen also appointed a waiting-maid to accompany the princess on her journey and formally present her to the bridegroom.
Each was provided with a horse for travel; the princess's horse, named Falada, was a unique gift from the fairy and possessed the magical ability to speak.

Prior to the princess setting out, the good fairy visited her bed-chamber, carefully cut a lock of her own hair, and presented it to the princess, explaining it was a charm that could offer assistance during the journey.
After a poignant farewell ceremony involving all present, the princess placed the lock of hair in her bosom, mounted Falada, and embarked on her voyage to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they all took a sorrowful leave of the princess; and she put the lock of hair into her bosom, got upon her horse, and set off on her journey to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

events.text_segment:
The king of a great land died, and left his queen to take care of their only child. This child was a daughter, who was very beautiful; and her mother loved her dearly, and was very kind to her. And there was a good fairy too, who was fond of the princess, and helped her mother to watch over her. When she grew up, she was betrothed to a prince who lived a great way off; and as the time drew near for her to be married, she got ready to set off on her journey to his country. Then the queen her mother, packed up a great many costly things; jewels, and gold, and silver; trinkets, fine dresses, and in short everything that became a royal bride. And she gave her a waiting-maid to ride with her, and give her into the bridegroom’s hands; and each had a horse for the journey. Now the princess’s horse was the fairy’s gift, and it was called Falada, and could speak.
When the time came for them to set out, the fairy went into her bed-chamber, and took a little knife, and cut off a lock of her hair, and gave it to the princess, and said, ‘Take care of it, dear child; for it is a charm that may be of use to you on the road.’ Then they all took a sorrowful leave of the princess; and she put the lock of hair into her bosom, got upon her horse, and set off on her journey to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

**Chapter Title:** *THE GOOSE-GIRL*

*The king of a great land died, and left his queen to take care of their only child.*

The queen, a woman of great strength and grace, devoted herself entirely to the upbringing of her daughter, whose beauty was said to rival the stars themselves. With the aid of a kind and wise Good Fairy, the princess was raised in a palace of splendor, her every need met with care and affection.

As the years passed, the princess came of age, and the queen arranged a marriage to a prince from a distant and powerful kingdom. The occasion was one of great celebration and preparation. The queen, with her own hands, gathered a vast collection of treasures—jewels that shimmered like the dawn, golden ornaments, delicate trinkets, and silken garments fit for a queen.

To accompany the princess on her journey, the queen chose a loyal and clever waiting-maid, who would serve as both companion and chaperone. Each was given a horse for the long and winding road ahead. The princess rode Falada, a noble steed gifted by the Good Fairy, whose unique gift was the ability to speak in a voice both gentle and wise.

Before the princess departed, the Good Fairy visited her in her chamber. With a solemn grace, she cut a lock of her own hair and placed it in the princess’s hands. “This is a charm,” she whispered, “to protect you and guide you when the path is dark.”

The day of departure arrived with a bittersweet air. The court gathered in the palace courtyard for a farewell ceremony, their voices raised in song and sorrow. The princess, her heart heavy with emotion, placed the lock of hair in her bosom and mounted Falada. With a final glance at her mother and the home she was leaving behind, she rode forth into the unknown, the wind carrying the echoes of her people’s hopes and prayers.

---

**End of Segment**

events.title: The Maid's First Act of Defiance and the Charm's Ominous Warning
detailed_summary: While traveling alongside a brook one day, the princess experienced great thirst and politely asked her waiting-maid to fetch her some water from the brook using her golden cup.
The maid defiantly retorted that if the princess was thirsty, she should dismount and get the water herself, declaring she would no longer act as her waiting-maid.
Feeling intensely thirsty and intimidated, the princess dismounted, knelt by the brook, and drank the water directly, too frightened to use her golden cup.

She wept in distress, questioning what would happen to her, at which point the lock of hair responded with a rhyming verse, lamenting how her mother would grieve if she knew of the princess's situation.
Being inherently gentle and meek, the princess did not comment on her maid's disrespectful conduct and simply remounted her horse to continue the journey.

events.text_segment:
One day, as they were riding along by a brook, the princess began to feel very thirsty: and she said to her maid, ‘Pray get down, and fetch me some water in my golden cup out of yonder brook, for I want to drink.’ ‘Nay,’ said the maid, ‘if you are thirsty, get off yourself, and stoop down by the water and drink; I shall not be your waiting-maid any longer.’ Then she was so thirsty that she got down, and knelt over the little brook, and drank; for she was frightened, and dared not bring out her golden cup; and she wept and said, ‘Alas! what will become of me?’ And the lock answered her, and said:
‘Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
But the princess was very gentle and meek, so she said nothing to her maid’s ill behaviour, but got upon her horse again.

events.title: The Loss of the Protective Charm and the Maid's Complete Usurpation of the Princess's Identity
detailed_summary: The party continued their journey until the day became exceedingly warm and the sun oppressively hot, causing the princess to feel extremely thirsty once more.
Upon reaching a river, having momentarily forgotten the maid's earlier rudeness, she requested water in her golden cup.
The maid responded with even greater insolence than before, firmly stating her refusal to act as a waiting-maid.
Overwhelmed by thirst, the princess dismounted, lay down, and leaned her head over the flowing stream to drink, crying out and wondering about her fate.
The lock of hair again offered its rhyming admonition.
As she bent down to drink, the precious lock of hair slipped from her bosom and was carried away by the water, an event the princess did not notice due to her distress.
Her maid, however, witnessed the loss of the hair, understood it was the charm, and gleefully realized that with the charm gone, the unfortunate bride would be entirely under her control.
Consequently, when the princess finished drinking and prepared to remount Falada, the maid asserted that she would ride Falada, compelling the princess to take the maid's horse instead.
Shortly thereafter, the maid forced the princess to relinquish her royal garments and wear the maid's own shabby attire.

events.text_segment:
Then all rode farther on their journey, till the day grew so warm, and the sun so scorching, that the bride began to feel very thirsty again; and at last, when they came to a river, she forgot her maid’s rude speech, and said, ‘Pray get down, and fetch me some water to drink in my golden cup.’ But the maid answered her, and even spoke more haughtily than before: ‘Drink if you will, but I shall not be your waiting-maid.’ Then the princess was so thirsty that she got off her horse, and lay down, and held her head over the running stream, and cried and said, ‘What will become of me?’ And the lock of hair answered her again:
‘Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
And as she leaned down to drink, the lock of hair fell from her bosom, and floated away with the water. Now she was so frightened that she did not see it; but her maid saw it, and was very glad, for she knew the charm; and she saw that the poor bride would be in her power, now that she had lost the hair. So when the bride had done drinking, and would have got upon Falada again, the maid said, ‘I shall ride upon Falada, and you may have my horse instead’; so she was forced to give up her horse, and soon afterwards to take off her royal clothes and put on her maid’s shabby ones.

events.title: The True Princess is Noticed by the Old King and Assigned as a Goose-Girl
detailed_summary: The old king, who happened to be unoccupied at that moment, was amusing himself by observing the courtyard activities from his kitchen window when he noticed the true princess.
He remarked on her striking beauty and delicate demeanor, which seemed incongruous for a mere waiting-maid.
Consequently, he ascended to the royal chamber to inquire of the (false) bride about the identity of the young woman she had brought and left standing in the court.
The false bride deceptively stated she had brought the girl for companionship on the road and requested that some work be assigned to her to prevent idleness.
After contemplating for a while, the old king decided that the princess could assist a lad named Curdken, who was responsible for tending the king's geese.

events.title: Falada's Execution Orchestrated by the False Bride and the Princess's Sorrowful Request
detailed_summary: The false bride approached the prince and requested, as a supposed act of kindness, that he order the execution of the horse she had ridden (Falada).
She falsely claimed the horse had been unruly and had caused her considerable trouble during the journey.
Her true motivation, however, was a deep-seated fear that Falada might one day speak and reveal her treachery towards the princess.
Her request was granted, and the faithful Falada was consequently killed.
Upon learning of Falada's demise, the true princess was overcome with grief and wept.
She implored the slaughterer to nail Falada's severed head against a large, dark city gate, a route she had to traverse every morning and evening, so that she might still have a chance to see him.
The slaughterer agreed to her wish, decapitated Falada, and securely nailed the head beneath the designated dark gate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But the false bride said to the prince, ‘Dear husband, pray do me one piece of kindness.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the slaughterer said he would do as she wished; and cut off the head, and nailed it up under the dark gate.

events.text_segment: But the false bride said to the prince, ‘Dear husband, pray do me one piece of kindness.’ ‘That I will,’ said the prince. ‘Then tell one of your slaughterers to cut off the head of the horse I rode upon, for it was very unruly, and plagued me sadly on the road’; but the truth was, she was very much afraid lest Falada should some day or other speak, and tell all she had done to the princess. She carried her point, and the faithful Falada was killed; but when the true princess heard of it, she wept, and begged the man to nail up Falada’s head against a large dark gate of the city, through which she had to pass every morning and evening, that there she might still see him sometimes. Then the slaughterer said he would do as she wished; and cut off the head, and nailed it up under the dark gate.

But the false bride said to the prince, ‘Dear husband, pray do me one piece of kindness.’

‘What is it you want?’ asked the prince.

‘The horse I rode has been so unruly and has given me much trouble on the journey,’ she said. ‘I would be so grateful if you would order him to be killed.’

The prince, not suspecting any harm, gave the order. The horse was led away and slaughtered.

The true princess, who had been standing nearby, was overcome with grief at the sight. She wept bitterly, for she had loved the horse dearly.

‘Please,’ she begged the slaughterer, ‘nail the horse’s head to the great black gate of the city, for I must pass by it every morning and evening, and then I shall still see him.’

The slaughterer did as she asked, and the head was nailed to the gate.

events.title: The Goose-Girl's Daily Rituals: Conversations with Falada's Head and Magical Hair Care
detailed_summary: Early the subsequent morning, as the princess (now a goose-girl) and Curdken passed through the city gate, she addressed Falada's mounted head with sorrow.
The head responded with a rhyming couplet, acknowledging her passage and lamenting that her mother was unaware of her current suffering.
They then proceeded out of the city to guide the geese to pasture.
Upon reaching the meadow, the princess sat down and let down her flowing locks of hair, which were all of pure silver.
When Curdken observed her hair glittering in the sunlight, he ran towards her with the intention of pulling some of the locks.
She, however, cried out a magical verse, imploring the breezes to blow away Curdken's hat.
A strong wind instantly arose, sweeping Curdken's hat off his head and carrying it far over the hills, compelling him to chase after it.
By the time Curdken managed to retrieve his hat and return, the princess had finished combing and curling her hair, securing it safely again.
Curdken became very angry and sulky at this, refusing to speak to her for the remainder of the day while they tended the geese until evening.

The following morning, this entire sequence—her sorrowful exchange with Falada's head at the gate, her hair ritual in the meadow, Curdken's attempt to grab her hair, her magical chant to the wind, his hat being blown away, and her subsequent grooming—repeated itself.

events.text_segment:
Early the next morning, as she and Curdken went out through the gate, she said sorrowfully:
‘Falada, Falada, there thou hangest!’
and the head answered:
‘Bride, bride, there thou gangest!
  Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
Then they went out of the city, and drove the geese on. And when she came to the meadow, she sat down upon a bank there, and let down her waving locks of hair, which were all of pure silver; and when Curdken saw it glitter in the sun, he ran up, and would have pulled some of the locks out, but she cried:
‘Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let Curdken’s hat go!
  Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let him after it go!
  O’er hills, dales, and rocks,
  Away be it whirl’d
  Till the silvery locks
  Are all comb’d and curl’d!
Then there came a wind, so strong that it blew off Curdken’s hat; and away it flew over the hills: and he was forced to turn and run after it; till, by the time he came back, she had done combing and curling her hair, and had put it up again safe. Then he was very angry and sulky, and would not speak to her at all; but they watched the geese until it grew dark in the evening, and then drove them homewards.
The next morning, as they were going through the dark gate, the poor girl looked up at Falada’s head, and cried:
‘Falada, Falada, there thou hangest!’
and the head answered:
‘Bride, bride, there thou gangest!
  Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
Then she drove on the geese, and sat down again in the meadow, and began to comb out her hair as before; and Curdken ran up to her, and wanted to take hold of it; but she cried out quickly:
‘Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let Curdken’s hat go!
  Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let him after it go!
  O’er hills, dales, and rocks,
  Away be it whirl’d
  Till the silvery locks
  Are all comb’d and curl’d!
Then the wind came and blew away his hat; and off it flew a great way, over the hills and far away, so that he had to run after it; and when he came back she had bound up her hair again, and all was safe. So they watched the geese till it grew dark.

**Simulated Output of `generate_literary_segment` Function:**

---

**Chapter Title:** *THE GOOSE-GIRL*

"Early the next morning, as she and Curdken went out through the gate, she said sorrowfully: 'O Falada, Falada, thou noble steed, why must I now be a goose-girl, and my mother not know of my sorrow?'"

The head of Falada, still mounted on the wall, answered in a voice that echoed with a strange, hollow dignity:  
"Because she sits in her high hall,  
And knows not of thy sorrow and pain.  
But I, who once was thy noble stall,  
Now speak to thee in this gate of stone and rain."

They rode out of the city, the geese trailing behind them like a procession of white spirits. The princess, now clad in coarse garments and with her royal bearing hidden beneath a humble hood, led the way with a quiet grace that even Curdken could not help but admire, though he tried to mask it with gruffness.

When they reached the meadow, the princess sat beneath a willow tree and let down her hair. It cascaded like a waterfall of silver, catching the light in a way that made the geese pause in their waddling to watch in silent awe. Curdken, seeing the shimmering strands, could not resist. He rushed forward, hand outstretched, intent on plucking a single lock.

But the princess, sensing his intent, cried out:  
"O breezes, breezes, blowing free,  
Carry away his hat from me!"

At once, a gust of wind rose from the hills, fierce and sudden. It caught Curdken’s hat and sent it spinning into the air, tumbling over the meadow and beyond the hills. He gave chase, shouting in frustration, while the princess calmly combed her hair, her face serene.

By the time he returned, breathless and red-faced, the princess had already resecured her hair in its intricate coils. She offered him no apology, and he, in turn, said nothing more to her for the rest of the day.

The next morning, the same scene repeated itself. At the gate, she spoke to Falada’s head, and it answered in rhyme. In the meadow, she let down her hair, and Curdken tried to steal a lock. She called upon the wind, and the hat flew again. And once more, he returned sullen and silent, the geese waddling on in their quiet procession, as if they, too, understood the silent drama unfolding before them.

"Early the next morning, as she and Curdken went out through the gate, she said sorrowfully: 'O Falada, Falada, thou noble steed, why must I now be a goose-girl, and my mother not know of my sorrow?'"

The head of Falada, still mounted on the wall, answered in a voice that echoed with a strange, hollow dignity:  
"Because she sits in her high hall,  
And knows not of thy sorrow and pain.  
But I, who once was thy noble stall,

They rode out of the city, the geese trailing behind them like a procession of white spirits. The princess, now clad in coarse garments and with her royal bearing hidden beneath a humble hood, led the way with a quiet grace that even Curdken could not help but admire, though he tried to mask it with gruffness.

"O breezes, breezes, blowing free,

events.text_segment:
In the evening, after they came home, Curdken went to the old king, and said, ‘I cannot have that strange girl to help me to keep the geese any longer.’ ‘Why?’ said the king. ‘Because, instead of doing any good, she does nothing but tease me all day long.’ Then the king made him tell him what had happened. And Curdken said, ‘When we go in the morning through the dark gate with our flock of geese, she cries and talks with the head of a horse that hangs upon the wall, and says:
‘Falada, Falada, there thou hangest!’
and the head answers:
‘Bride, bride, there thou gangest!
  Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
And Curdken went on telling the king what had happened upon the meadow where the geese fed; how his hat was blown away; and how he was forced to run after it, and to leave his flock of geese to themselves. But the old king told the boy to go out again the next day: and when morning came, he placed himself behind the dark gate, and heard how she spoke to Falada, and how Falada answered. Then he went into the field, and hid himself in a bush by the meadow’s side; and he soon saw with his own eyes how they drove the flock of geese; and how, after a little time, she let down her hair that glittered in the sun. And then he heard her say:
‘Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let Curdken’s hat go!
  Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let him after it go!
  O’er hills, dales, and rocks,
  Away be it whirl’d
  Till the silvery locks
  Are all comb’d and curl’d!
And soon came a gale of wind, and carried away Curdken’s hat, and away went Curdken after it, while the girl went on combing and curling her hair. All this the old king saw: so he went home without being seen; and when the little goose-girl came back in the evening he called her aside, and asked her why she did so: but she burst into tears, and said, ‘That I must not tell you or any man, or I shall lose my life.’

In the evening, after they came home, Curdken went to the old king, and said, ‘I cannot have that strange girl to help me to keep the geese any longer.’ The old king asked, ‘Why not?’ Curdken replied, ‘She is always so quiet and does not speak, and I do not like that. I want someone who will talk and laugh and make the work seem lighter.’ The old king thought for a moment and said, ‘Very well, you may have another girl to help you.’

The next morning, a new girl came to help Curdken with the geese. She was very talkative and laughed a great deal, and Curdken was very pleased. When the old king found out, he was very angry.

‘You have been careless,’ he said to the new girl. ‘You must go.’ The girl was sent away, and the strange girl was brought back. Curdken was not happy, but he had to take her again. This time, he tried to be kind to her and asked her questions. To his surprise, she answered him in a soft voice, and he found that she was very wise and clever.

One day, while they were tending the geese, Curdken saw something strange. The girl was talking to a goose, and the goose was listening. He thought she was just playing, but later he noticed that the goose was different from the others. It had a golden feather that shone in the sunlight. Curdken asked the girl about it, and she said, ‘This is a special goose. It will help us in the future.’

Curdken did not understand, but he trusted her. He began to care for the goose as if it were a treasure. Soon, the goose laid a golden egg every day, and the old king was very pleased. He gave Curdken many gifts and praised him for his good care of the geese.

But the old king was still very old and weak, and he knew that he would not live much longer. He called Curdken to him and said, ‘You have been a good shepherd, and I wish to make you my successor. But there is a task you must complete before you can be king.’

Curdken asked, ‘What is the task?’ The old king said, ‘You must find the golden goose’s true home, where it was born. Only then will you be ready to rule.’

events.title: The Goose-Girl Reveals Her True Story, is Recognized, and the King Plans a Public Revelation
detailed_summary: The old king persisted with his gentle entreaties, giving the goose-girl no peace until she finally recounted her entire story to him, from the very beginning to the end, word for word.
Her decision to confide in him proved to be very fortunate, as upon hearing her tale, the king immediately ordered that royal clothes be brought for her.
He gazed upon her with wonder, marveling at her beauty, now fully apparent in her proper attire.

The king then summoned his son, the young king, and revealed to him that he had been deceived: the woman he believed to be his bride was merely a waiting-maid, while the true bride stood there before them.
The young king rejoiced immensely upon seeing her beauty and hearing of her gentle and patient nature.
Without alerting the false bride to these developments, the old king commanded that a great feast be prepared for the entire court.

At the feast, the bridegroom was seated at the head of the table, with the false princess on one side and the true princess on the other; however, no one recognized the true princess, as her beauty was quite dazzling to their eyes, and she seemed entirely different from the little goose-girl now that she wore her brilliant dress.

events.title: The Imposter's Self-Condemnation, the True Couple's Marriage, and Falada's Restoration
detailed_summary: Once everyone had eaten and drunk and were in high spirits, the old king announced he would tell them a tale.
He then proceeded to narrate the entire story of the princess's ordeals, presenting it as if it were a story he had once heard.
Upon concluding, he turned to the true waiting-maid (the imposter bride) and asked her what she believed would be an appropriate punishment for someone who would behave in such a treacherous manner.

The false bride, oblivious to her own impending doom, declared that such a person deserved nothing better than to be thrown into a cask studded all around with sharp nails, and then have two white horses drag the cask from street to street until she was dead.
The old king then solemnly declared, 'Thou art she! And as thou has judged thyself, so shall it be done to thee.'
Following this judgment, the young king was married to his true wife, and they reigned together over the kingdom in peace and happiness for all their lives.
The good fairy later came to visit them and, in a final act of benevolence, restored the faithful Falada to life again.

chapters.chapter_title: THE ADVENTURES OF CHANTICLEER AND PARTLET

events.title: A Journey to the Mountains and a Forced Cart Driver
detailed_summary: Chanticleer suggests to his wife Partlet that they go to the mountains to eat ripe nuts before the squirrel gets them all, and Partlet agrees.
They spend a lovely day in the mountains and stay until evening.
Having eaten so many nuts, or perhaps due to laziness, they decide against walking home.
Chanticleer constructs a small carriage from nutshells.
Partlet gets into the carriage and tells Chanticleer to harness himself and pull her home.
Chanticleer refuses, stating he would rather walk, but offers to be the coachman if Partlet pulls, an offer which is implicitly rejected.
A duck appears, quacking angrily and accusing them of trespassing on her grounds.
The duck attacks Chanticleer.
Chanticleer, being brave, retaliates effectively with his spurs, forcing the duck to beg for mercy.
Mercy is granted on the condition that the duck pulls their carriage home.
The duck agrees, Chanticleer gets on the box as coachman, and they set off at a good speed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘The nuts are quite ripe now,’ said Chanticleer to his wife Partlet, ‘suppose we go together to the mountains, and eat as many as we can, before the squirrel takes them all away.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And away they went at a pretty good pace.

events.text_segment:
‘The nuts are quite ripe now,’ said Chanticleer to his wife Partlet, ‘suppose we go together to the mountains, and eat as many as we can, before the squirrel takes them all away.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said Partlet, ‘let us go and make a holiday of it together.’
So they went to the mountains; and as it was a lovely day, they stayed there till the evening. Now, whether it was that they had eaten so many nuts that they could not walk, or whether they were lazy and would not, I do not know: however, they took it into their heads that it did not become them to go home on foot. So Chanticleer began to build a little carriage of nutshells: and when it was finished, Partlet jumped into it and sat down, and bid Chanticleer harness himself to it and draw her home. ‘That’s a good joke!’ said Chanticleer; ‘no, that will never do; I had rather by half walk home; I’ll sit on the box and be coachman, if you like, but I’ll not draw.’ While this was passing, a duck came quacking up and cried out, ‘You thieving vagabonds, what business have you in my grounds? I’ll give it you well for your insolence!’ and upon that she fell upon Chanticleer most lustily. But Chanticleer was no coward, and returned the duck’s blows with his sharp spurs so fiercely that she soon began to cry out for mercy; which was only granted her upon condition that she would draw the carriage home for them. This she agreed to do; and Chanticleer got upon the box, and drove, crying, ‘Now, duck, get on as fast as you can.’ And away they went at a pretty good pace.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The nuts are quite ripe now,

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: ‘The nuts are quite ripe now,’ said Chanticleer to his wife Partlet, ‘suppose we go together to the mountains, and eat as many as we can, before the squirrel takes them all away.’ Partlet, who was a very plump and contented hen, agreed at once. She fluffed up her feathers and clapped her wings with delight. 'I have been longing for a little outing,' she said. 'It will be a fine adventure, and I am sure the nuts will be delicious.' So they set off together, Chanticleer strutting proudly in front, and Partlet following with a happy cluck. As they walked through the forest, Chanticleer began to crow loudly, for he was proud of his fine voice and loved to show it off. 'Cock-a-doodle-doo!' he cried. 'I am the king of the birds, and no one can sing like me!' But just as he finished his song, a fox who was hiding behind a bush heard him. 'Ah,' said the fox, 'there is a fine meal for me. I must catch that rooster.' The fox crept closer and closer, his eyes gleaming with hunger. But Chanticleer, who was very clever, noticed the fox's shadow. 'What is that?' he asked. 'Is it a cloud?' 'No,' said Partlet, 'it is a fox.' 'Then we must be off,' said Chanticleer. 'I have heard that foxes are very cunning.' So they ran as fast as they could, and the fox ran after them. But Chanticleer was quick and clever, and he led the fox on a long chase through the forest. At last, the fox tired and gave up, and Chanticleer and Partlet reached the mountains safely. There they found plenty of ripe nuts and enjoyed a fine feast together. 'We must be more careful next time,' said Chanticleer. 'It is not safe to sing so loudly in the forest.' 'No,' said Partlet, 'but it was a fine adventure, and I am very glad we went.' And so they returned home, happy and content, and never again sang so loudly in the forest.

events.title: Acquiring New Passengers and Reaching the Inn
detailed_summary: While travelling, they encounter a needle and a pin walking together.
The needle calls for them to stop, explaining it's very dark, the path is muddy, and they can hardly see.
The needle recounts that he and the pin had been drinking at a public-house and lost track of time.
He requests a ride in their carriage for himself and the pin.
Chanticleer, seeing they are thin and won't take up much space, agrees to give them a lift.
He makes them promise not to dirty the carriage wheels or step on Partlet’s toes.
Late at night, they arrive at an inn.
Deciding it's too difficult to travel in the dark and noting the duck's exhaustion (as it waddled significantly), they decide to stay at the inn.
The landlord is initially reluctant, saying his inn is full, suspecting they might not be respectable guests.
However, they speak politely to him and offer him an egg Partlet laid en route, and also promise him the duck, mentioning its habit of laying an egg daily.
Persuaded, the landlord allows them in; they order a fine supper and enjoy a merry evening.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After they had travelled along a little way, they met a needle and a pin walking together along the road: and the needle cried out, ‘Stop, stop!’ and said it was so dark that they could hardly find their way, and such dirty walking they could not get on at all: he told them that he and his friend, the pin, had been at a public-house a few miles off, and had sat drinking till they had forgotten how late it was; he begged therefore that the travellers would be so kind as to give them a lift in their carriage.

events.text_segment:
After they had travelled along a little way, they met a needle and a pin walking together along the road: and the needle cried out, ‘Stop, stop!’ and said it was so dark that they could hardly find their way, and such dirty walking they could not get on at all: he told them that he and his friend, the pin, had been at a public-house a few miles off, and had sat drinking till they had forgotten how late it was; he begged therefore that the travellers would be so kind as to give them a lift in their carriage. Chanticleer observing that they were but thin fellows, and not likely to take up much room, told them they might ride, but made them promise not to dirty the wheels of the carriage in getting in, nor to tread on Partlet’s toes.
Late at night they arrived at an inn; and as it was bad travelling in the dark, and the duck seemed much tired, and waddled about a good deal from one side to the other, they made up their minds to fix their quarters there: but the landlord at first was unwilling, and said his house was full, thinking they might not be very respectable company: however, they spoke civilly to him, and gave him the egg which Partlet had laid by the way, and said they would give him the duck, who was in the habit of laying one every day: so at last he let them come in, and they bespoke a handsome supper, and spent the evening very jollily.

events.title: Morning Mischief and Stealthy Departure
detailed_summary: Very early the next morning, before daylight and while everyone else in the inn is asleep, Chanticleer wakes Partlet.
They retrieve the egg they had given the landlord, peck a hole in it, eat it, and discard the shells into the fireplace.
They then approach the pin and needle, who are sound asleep.
They seize the pin and needle by their heads and stick one into the landlord's easy chair and the other into his handkerchief.
After completing their mischief, Chanticleer and Partlet sneak away as quietly as possible.
The duck, who was sleeping outside in the yard, hears them leaving.
The duck jumps into a nearby brook and swims away, out of their reach.

events.title: The Innkeeper's Painful Discoveries and Vow
detailed_summary: About an hour or two later, the landlord gets up.
He takes his handkerchief to wipe his face but is pricked by the pin hidden within it.
He then goes to the kitchen to light his pipe at the fire.
When he stirs the fire, the eggshells (left by Chanticleer and Partlet) fly into his eyes, nearly blinding him.
The landlord exclaims in distress, feeling as if the entire world is conspiring against his head that morning.
Still upset, he throws himself sulkily into his easy chair.
He is then painfully pricked by the needle hidden in the chair, with the pain not being in his head this time.
Enraged, and suspecting the guests from the previous night, he goes to find them but discovers they have all left.
He furiously swears never again to accommodate such a group of troublemakers, who consumed much, paid nothing, and only left behind their malicious pranks as 'thanks'.

He now flew into a very great passion, and, suspecting the company who had come in the night before, he went to look after them, but they were all off; so he swore that he never again would take in such a troop of vagabonds, who ate a great deal, paid no reckoning, and gave him nothing for his trouble but their apish tricks.

events.title: A New Carriage and a Growing Entourage for Mr. Korbes's Visit
detailed_summary: On another occasion, Chanticleer and Partlet wanted to go for a ride together.
Chanticleer constructed an impressive carriage equipped with four red wheels and harnessed six mice to pull it.
He and Partlet then boarded the carriage and set off.
Shortly after, they encountered a cat, who inquired about their destination.
Chanticleer poetically replied that they were on their way to visit Mr. Korbes, the fox.
The cat asked to accompany them.
Chanticleer agreed willingly, instructing the cat to get up behind and to be careful not to fall off.
He then gave a rhyming command, urging care for his coach and wheels, and readiness from the mice, as they journeyed to Mr. Korbes.
Soon after, a millstone, an egg, a duck, and a pin also approached, and Chanticleer permitted all of them to join the group in the carriage for the visit.

events.text_segment:
Another day, Chanticleer and Partlet wished to ride out together; so Chanticleer built a handsome carriage with four red wheels, and harnessed six mice to it; and then he and Partlet got into the carriage, and away they drove. Soon afterwards a cat met them, and said, ‘Where are you going?’ And Chanticleer replied,
‘All on our way
  A visit to pay
  To Mr Korbes, the fox, today.’
Then the cat said, ‘Take me with you,’ Chanticleer said, ‘With all my heart: get up behind, and be sure you do not fall off.’
‘Take care of this handsome coach of mine,
  Nor dirty my pretty red wheels so fine!
  Now, mice, be ready,
  And, wheels, run steady!
  For we are going a visit to pay
  To Mr Korbes, the fox, today.’
Soon after came up a millstone, an egg, a duck, and a pin; and Chanticleer gave them all leave to get into the carriage and go with them.

events.title: Mr. Korbes's Fatal Welcome Home
detailed_summary: When Mr. Korbes returned home, he went to the fireplace intending to start a fire.
However, the cat, hidden there, threw all the ashes into his eyes.
Mr. Korbes then rushed to the kitchen to wash his face.
There, the duck splashed all the water into his face.
As he attempted to dry himself with a towel, the egg, hidden within, broke, smearing its contents all over his face and eyes.
Infuriated by these events, Mr. Korbes decided to skip supper and go straight to bed.
But as he laid his head on the pillow, the pin stuck into his cheek.
This made him completely furious; he jumped up and tried to flee the house.
As he reached the door, the millstone, positioned above, fell down onto his head, killing him instantly.

events.title: Partlet's Fatal Greed and Chanticleer's Desperate Quest for Water
detailed_summary: On another occasion, Chanticleer and Partlet decided to return to the mountains for nuts, agreeing to share their findings equally.
Partlet discovered an exceptionally large nut but chose not to tell Chanticleer, keeping it for herself.
The nut was so large that she couldn't swallow it, and it became lodged in her throat.
Terrified, she cried out to Chanticleer, begging him to run quickly and fetch water to prevent her from choking.
Chanticleer ran as fast as possible to the river, pleading for water for Partlet, who was on the mountain choking on a large nut.
The river instructed him to first go to a bride and ask her for a silken cord to draw the water.
Chanticleer hurried to the bride, requesting the silken cord so the river would give him water for the choking Partlet.
The bride, in turn, told him to first retrieve her garland, which was hanging on a willow in the garden.
Chanticleer ran to the garden, took the garland from the bough, and brought it to the bride.
The bride then gave him the silken cord.
He took the cord to the river, and the river provided the water.
Chanticleer carried the water to Partlet, but by then, she had already choked to death on the nut and lay completely still.

events.text_segment: Another day Chanticleer and Partlet agreed to go again to the mountains to eat nuts; and it was settled that all the nuts which they found should be shared equally between them. Now Partlet found a very large nut; but she said nothing about it to Chanticleer, and kept it all to herself: however, it was so big that she could not swallow it, and it stuck in her throat. Then she was in a great fright, and cried out to Chanticleer, ‘Pray run as fast as you can, and fetch me some water, or I shall be choked.’ Chanticleer ran as fast as he could to the river, and said, ‘River, give me some water, for Partlet lies in the mountain, and will be choked by a great nut.’ The river said, ‘Run first to the bride, and ask her for a silken cord to draw up the water.’ Chanticleer ran to the bride, and said, ‘Bride, you must give me a silken cord, for then the river will give me water, and the water I will carry to Partlet, who lies on the mountain, and will be choked by a great nut.’ But the bride said, ‘Run first, and bring me my garland that is hanging on a willow in the garden.’ Then Chanticleer ran to the garden, and took the garland from the bough where it hung, and brought it to the bride; and then the bride gave him the silken cord, and he took the silken cord to the river, and the river gave him water, and he carried the water to Partlet; but in the meantime she was choked by the great nut, and lay quite dead, and never moved any more.

Chanticleer ran as fast as he could to the river and said, 'O River, give me some water, for Partlet is choking on a nut.' The River said, 'Go first to the Bride and get a silken cord from her, and then I will give you water.' So Chanticleer ran to the Bride and said, 'O Bride, give me a silken cord, for the River will give me water for Partlet if I bring it.' The Bride said, 'Go first and bring me my garland, which is hanging on a willow in the garden.' Chanticleer ran to the garden, took the garland from the willow, and brought it to the Bride. The Bride then gave him the silken cord. Chanticleer took the cord to the River, and the River gave him water. Chanticleer ran back to Partlet with the water, but when he arrived, she was already dead, and lay quite still.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Another day Chanticleer and Partlet agreed to go again to the mountains to eat nuts; and it was settled that all the nuts which they found should be shared equally between them. So they set out together, and when they came to the mountains they found a great many nuts lying on the ground. Chanticleer began to pick them up and put them into a little bag which he carried on his back. Partlet, who was very light and nimble, flew about and helped him as much as she could. When they had gathered a good supply, they sat down to rest and to count their treasure. Chanticleer said, 'Now we must divide these nuts fairly, as we agreed.' So he took out a long stick and divided the pile into two equal parts. But when he looked at the two piles, he saw that one was a little bigger than the other. 'This is not fair,' he said. 'I will take the smaller pile, and you may have the bigger one.' Partlet was very much surprised at this. 'Why, Chanticleer,' she said, 'you are always so just and kind. I thought you would take the bigger pile for yourself.' 'No,' said Chanticleer, 'I would rather be just than selfish. I will take the smaller pile, and you may have the bigger one.' So he took the smaller pile and went away, leaving Partlet to take the bigger one. And from that day forward, Chanticleer and Partlet were never seen together again.

events.title: Partlet's Funeral Procession Begins
detailed_summary: Chanticleer was overcome with sorrow and wept intensely.
All the beasts of the area gathered and mourned with him over Partlet's death.
Six mice constructed a small hearse to transport Partlet to her grave.
Once the hearse was ready, the mice harnessed themselves to it, and Chanticleer drove them.
During their journey, they encountered the fox.
The fox inquired where Chanticleer was going, and Chanticleer replied he was going to bury Partlet.
The fox asked if he could join them.
Chanticleer agreed but stipulated that the fox must get up behind, as his 'horses' (the mice) wouldn't be able to pull his weight otherwise.
The fox complied, and soon after, the wolf, the bear, the goat, and all the other animals of the wood arrived and also climbed onto the hearse.

events.text_segment: Then Chanticleer was very sorry, and cried bitterly; and all the beasts came and wept with him over poor Partlet. And six mice built a little hearse to carry her to her grave; and when it was ready they harnessed themselves before it, and Chanticleer drove them. On the way they met the fox. ‘Where are you going, Chanticleer?’ said he. ‘To bury my Partlet,’ said the other. ‘May I go with you?’ said the fox. ‘Yes; but you must get up behind, or my horses will not be able to draw you.’ Then the fox got up behind; and presently the wolf, the bear, the goat, and all the beasts of the wood, came and climbed upon the hearse.

events.title: Tragedy at the Stream and Chanticleer's Final Demise
detailed_summary: The funeral procession continued until they reached a swiftly flowing stream.
Chanticleer wondered how they would cross.
A straw offered to lay itself across the stream for them to pass over.
However, as the mice were crossing, the straw slipped and fell into the water, causing all six mice to fall in and drown.
Faced with this dilemma, a large log of wood appeared, declaring itself big enough to serve as a bridge.
The log laid itself across the stream, but due to clumsy maneuvering, it too fell into the water and was swept away.
Then, a stone that had witnessed these events kindly offered to help by laying itself across the stream.
This time, Chanticleer managed to get safely to the other side with the hearse and retrieve Partlet's body from it.

Unfortunately, the fox and the other mourners (wolf, bear, goat, etc.) who were riding behind on the hearse were too heavy; the hearse presumably tipped or they fell, and they all tumbled into the water, were carried away by the current, and drowned.
Chanticleer was thus left entirely alone with the deceased Partlet.
He dug a grave for her, laid her in it, and created a small mound over her.
He then sat by her grave, weeping and mourning, until he eventually died as well, marking the death of everyone involved in this final story.

events.text_segment:
So on they went till they came to a rapid stream. ‘How shall we get over?’ said Chanticleer. Then said a straw, ‘I will lay myself across, and you may pass over upon me.’ But as the mice were going over, the straw slipped away and fell into the water, and the six mice all fell in and were drowned. What was to be done? Then a large log of wood came and said, ‘I am big enough; I will lay myself across the stream, and you shall pass over upon me.’ So he laid himself down; but they managed so clumsily, that the log of wood fell in and was carried away by the stream. Then a stone, who saw what had happened, came up and kindly offered to help poor Chanticleer by laying himself across the stream; and this time he got safely to the other side with the hearse, and managed to get Partlet out of it; but the fox and the other mourners, who were sitting behind, were too heavy, and fell back into the water and were all carried away by the stream and drowned.
Thus Chanticleer was left alone with his dead Partlet; and having dug a grave for her, he laid her in it, and made a little hillock over her. Then he sat down by the grave, and wept and mourned, till at last he died too; and so all were dead.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: So on they went till they came to a rapid stream. The stream was so wide and so fast that it seemed impossible to cross. The girl looked around and saw a small boat tied to a tree on the bank. "Perhaps we can use this," she said. Her brother, however, was not so sure. "It looks old and worn. It might not hold up to the current," he replied. But the girl was determined. She untied the boat and pushed it into the water. It floated, though it creaked and groaned as if it were about to fall apart. They climbed in, and the girl took the oars. The current was strong, and the boat was tossed about, but she rowed with all her might. Just as they reached the middle of the stream, a great wave crashed over the boat, nearly capsizing it. The girl held on tightly, her heart pounding. With one final push, they reached the other side, soaked but safe. As they stepped onto the solid ground, they looked back and saw the boat begin to drift away, carried off by the current. They had no time to think about it, for they heard a low growl behind them. Turning around, they saw a large wolf standing at the edge of the stream, its eyes gleaming with hunger. The girl grabbed her brother's hand and they ran, deeper into the forest, the wolf close behind. They had no idea what awaited them in the woods, but they knew they had to keep going if they wanted to survive."

events.title: The Rampion Craving and the Fateful Bargain
detailed_summary: A husband and wife had long wished for a child without success.
Eventually, the wife became pregnant and developed an overwhelming craving for rampion she saw in a neighboring enchantress's garden.
She felt she would die if she couldn't eat it, becoming pale and miserable.
Her alarmed husband, prioritizing her health, decided to get the rampion for her, whatever the cost.
At twilight, he climbed the wall into the enchantress's garden, quickly gathered a handful of rampion, and brought it to his wife.
She immediately prepared a salad from it and ate it with great satisfaction.
The rampion tasted so exceptionally good that the next day her craving became three times stronger.
To find peace, the husband knew he had to venture into the garden again.
As he let himself down into the garden in the evening gloom, he was terrified to find the enchantress standing before him.
The enchantress angrily accused him of thievery and threatened punishment.
The husband pleaded for mercy, explaining his actions were born of necessity as his wife would have died from her longing for the rampion.
The enchantress's anger softened, and she proposed a deal: he could take all the rampion he wished, on the condition that he give her the child his wife would soon bear.
She promised to treat the child well and care for it like a mother.
In his terror, the man agreed to everything.
When the woman gave birth, the enchantress appeared immediately, named the child Rapunzel, and took her away.

events.text_segment: There were once a man and a woman who had long in vain wished for a child. At length the woman hoped that God was about to grant her desire. These people had a little window at the back of their house from which a splendid garden could be seen, which was full of the most beautiful flowers and herbs. It was, however, surrounded by a high wall, and no one dared to go into it because it belonged to an enchantress, who had great power and was dreaded by all the world. One day the woman was standing by this window and looking down into the garden, when she saw a bed which was planted with the most beautiful rampion (rapunzel), and it looked so fresh and green that she longed for it, she quite pined away, and began to look pale and miserable. Then her husband was alarmed, and asked: ‘What ails you, dear wife?’ ‘Ah,’ she replied, ‘if I can’t eat some of the rampion, which is in the garden behind our house, I shall die.’ The man, who loved her, thought: ‘Sooner than let your wife die, bring her some of the rampion yourself, let it cost what it will.’ At twilight, he clambered down over the wall into the garden of the enchantress, hastily clutched a handful of rampion, and took it to his wife. She at once made herself a salad of it, and ate it greedily. It tasted so good to her—so very good, that the next day she longed for it three times as much as before. If he was to have any rest, her husband must once more descend into the garden. In the gloom of evening therefore, he let himself down again; but when he had clambered down the wall he was terribly afraid, for he saw the enchantress standing before him. ‘How can you dare,’ said she with angry look, ‘descend into my garden and steal my rampion like a thief? You shall suffer for it!’ ‘Ah,’ answered he, ‘let mercy take the place of justice, I only made up my mind to do it out of necessity. My wife saw your rampion from the window, and felt such a longing for it that she would have died if she had not got some to eat.’ Then the enchantress allowed her anger to be softened, and said to him: ‘If the case be as you say, I will allow you to take away with you as much rampion as you will, only I make one condition, you must give me the child which your wife will bring into the world; it shall be well treated, and I will care for it like a mother.’ The man in his terror consented to everything, and when the woman was brought to bed, the enchantress appeared at once, gave the child the name of Rapunzel, and took it away with her.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There were once a man and a woman who had long in vain wished for a child. When at last the wife became pregnant, she began to long for rampion, which grew in great abundance in the garden of a sorceress who lived nearby. She became so pale and wretched that she would not take food, and said she would rather die than live without rampion. Her husband, who loved her dearly, was so alarmed at her condition that he resolved to get her some rampion, even though he knew it would cost him his life. One evening, when the sun had set and it was already twilight, he climbed over the wall into the sorceress’s garden, and quickly gathered a handful of rampion. He brought it home and his wife made a salad of it, and ate it with great satisfaction. The next day, however, her longing for rampion was three times as strong as before. Her husband, in order to find peace, had to go to the garden again. But when he was just letting himself down into the garden in the evening gloom, the sorceress came up behind him and said, “So, you have stolen from me twice, and you will not escape with your life a third time.” The poor man was so frightened that he fell on his knees and begged for mercy, saying that he had done it only out of necessity, for his wife would have died from longing for the rampion. The sorceress, however, was not softened by his words, but said, “You may have as much rampion as you wish, but you must give me the child your wife will soon bear, and I will raise it as my own.” The man, in great fear, agreed to everything. When the time came for the wife to give birth, the sorceress appeared at once, took the child, and named it Rapunzel. Then she took the little girl away with her.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: There were once a man and a woman who had long in vain wished for a child. At last the woman became pregnant and gave birth to a son. They rejoiced greatly, but the mother was so weak from the birth that she died a few days later. The father was very sad, but he did his best to bring up the child alone. He loved the boy dearly and gave him everything he needed. When the boy was seven years old, the father married again. His new wife was a proud and selfish woman who did not like the boy at all. She treated him badly and gave him only the worst clothes and the least food. The boy had to work hard and was often beaten. One day, the stepmother said to her own two daughters, “Tomorrow we are going to the forest to gather flowers. Take your brother with you and tell him to pick flowers too.” The sisters were cruel and laughed at the boy. They took him to the forest and left him there alone. The boy cried and cried, but no one came to help him. He wandered through the forest for hours until he came to a small cottage. The door was open, so he went in. Inside, he found a little old woman who was very kind. “Don’t cry, child,” she said. “You can stay here with me. I will take care of you.” The old woman gave the boy food and a warm bed. She told him that she was a witch and that she had been waiting for someone to come to her cottage. From then on, the boy lived with the witch. He worked for her, but she was kind and gave him everything he needed. The witch had a magic spinning wheel, and she taught the boy how to use it. One day, the boy was told that his father was very ill and wanted to see him. The witch gave him a spinning wheel and said, “If you ever need help, spin the wheel and say, ‘Spinning wheel, spinning wheel, help me now.’” The boy went to his father’s house, but his stepmother did not let him in. The father was too weak to argue, and the boy had to go back to the witch. Soon after, the father died, and the stepmother and her daughters were left alone. They were very poor and had no money to buy food. One day, the stepmother said, “We must go to the forest to find something to eat.” They went to the forest and found the boy’s cottage. The witch was not there, so they went inside. The stepmother saw the spinning wheel and said, “This is a fine thing. I will take it home with me.” She took the spinning wheel and went back to her house. That night, she sat down and began to spin. As soon as she touched the wheel, it pricked her finger and she fell down dead. Her daughters tried to use the wheel too, but it pricked them as well, and they died too. The boy was very sad, but he was also free at last. He went back to the cottage and lived with the witch until she died. Then he became a man and lived happily ever after.

events.title: Rapunzel's Tower Imprisonment
detailed_summary: Rapunzel blossomed into the most beautiful child imaginable.
Upon her twelfth birthday, the enchantress imprisoned her in a tower situated in a forest.
This tower was unique as it had no stairs or door, only a small window at its very peak.
When the enchantress wished to enter, she would position herself beneath the window and call out: ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,  Let down your hair to me.’
Rapunzel possessed magnificent long hair, as fine as spun gold.
Upon hearing the enchantress's voice, she would unfasten her braided tresses, loop them around a window hook, and let her hair cascade twenty ells down, enabling the enchantress to climb up.

events.title: The Prince Discovers Rapunzel and Her Song
detailed_summary: A year or two later, a king's son chanced upon the tower while riding through the forest.
He was captivated by a charming song and paused to listen; it was Rapunzel, singing to alleviate her solitude.
The prince desired to reach her and searched for an entrance to the tower but found none.
He returned home, yet the memory of her singing deeply affected him, compelling him to visit the forest daily to hear it.
During one such visit, while concealed behind a tree, he observed an enchantress approach the tower.
He heard her call out: ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,  Let down your hair to me.’
He then watched as Rapunzel lowered her braids, allowing the enchantress to ascend.
Realizing this was the method of entry, the prince resolved to try his luck.
The following day, as twilight approached, he went to the tower and made the same call: ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,  Let down your hair to me.’
Instantly, the hair descended, and the king's son climbed up.

events.text_segment:
After a year or two, it came to pass that the king’s son rode through the forest and passed by the tower. Then he heard a song, which was so charming that he stood still and listened. This was Rapunzel, who in her solitude passed her time in letting her sweet voice resound. The king’s son wanted to climb up to her, and looked for the door of the tower, but none was to be found. He rode home, but the singing had so deeply touched his heart, that every day he went out into the forest and listened to it. Once when he was thus standing behind a tree, he saw that an enchantress came there, and he heard how she cried:
‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,
  Let down your hair to me.’
Then Rapunzel let down the braids of her hair, and the enchantress climbed up to her. ‘If that is the ladder by which one mounts, I too will try my fortune,’ said he, and the next day when it began to grow dark, he went to the tower and cried:
‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,
  Let down your hair to me.’
Immediately the hair fell down and the king’s son climbed up.

Her voice, they say, can still be heard on quiet evenings, echoing through the trees, a reminder of love lost and the magic of the forest.

events.title: The Prince and Rapunzel's Secret Love and Escape Plan
detailed_summary: Rapunzel was initially terrified by the sight of the prince, a type of man she had never encountered before.
However, the king's son spoke to her gently, as a friend, explaining that her captivating song had stirred his heart so deeply he had no rest until he saw her.
His kind words allayed Rapunzel's fear.
When he asked her to be his wife, she considered his youth and handsome appearance and thought he would offer more love than 'old Dame Gothel' (the enchantress).
She agreed to his proposal and placed her hand in his.
Rapunzel expressed her desire to leave with him but acknowledged the challenge of escaping the tower.
She proposed a plan: he should bring a skein of silk with him on each visit, which she would use to weave a ladder.
Once the ladder was complete, she would descend, and he would carry her away on his horse.
They arranged for him to visit her every evening, as the enchantress only came during the day.

Bring with you a skein of silk every time that you come, and I will weave a ladder with it, and when that is ready I will descend, and you will take me on your horse.’ They agreed that until that time he should come to her every evening, for the old woman came by day.

events.title: Discovery of the Secret and Rapunzel's Banishment
detailed_summary: The enchantress remained unaware of these developments for some time.
However, Rapunzel inadvertently revealed the secret one day.
She asked Dame Gothel why she was so much heavier to pull up the tower compared to the young king's son, who ascended in an instant.
The enchantress reacted with outrage, exclaiming at Rapunzel's wickedness and perceived betrayal.
She lamented that despite her efforts to isolate Rapunzel from the world, she had been deceived.
In a fit of anger, she seized Rapunzel's beautiful hair, wrapped it twice around her left hand, took a pair of scissors, and cut off the braids, which fell to the ground.
Her cruelty extended further as she then transported poor Rapunzel to a desert, condemning her to a life of profound grief and misery.

events.text_segment: The enchantress remarked nothing of this, until once Rapunzel said to her: ‘Tell me, Dame Gothel, how it happens that you are so much heavier for me to draw up than the young king’s son—he is with me in a moment.’ ‘Ah! you wicked child,’ cried the enchantress. ‘What do I hear you say! I thought I had separated you from all the world, and yet you have deceived me!’ In her anger she clutched Rapunzel’s beautiful tresses, wrapped them twice round her left hand, seized a pair of scissors with the right, and snip, snap, they were cut off, and the lovely braids lay on the ground. And she was so pitiless that she took poor Rapunzel into a desert where she had to live in great grief and misery.

events.title: The Enchantress's Deception and the Prince's Blinding
detailed_summary: On the same day she exiled Rapunzel, the enchantress took the severed braids of hair and attached them to the window hook.
When the king's son arrived and called out the familiar request for Rapunzel to let down her hair.
The enchantress lowered the cut braids.
The king's son climbed up, only to be met not by his beloved Rapunzel, but by the enchantress, who glared at him with malicious and poisonous looks.
She taunted him, saying his 'dearest' was gone, like a bird flown from its nest, and that the 'cat' (herself) had taken it and would also harm him.
She declared that Rapunzel was lost to him forever and he would never see her again.
Overcome with immense pain and despair, the king's son leaped from the tower.
He survived the fall, but the thorns he landed in pierced his eyes, leaving him blind.

  Let down your hair to me.’
she let the hair down. Rapunzel is lost to you; you will never see her again.’ The king’s son was beside himself with pain, and in his despair he leapt down from the tower. He escaped with his life, but the thorns into which he fell pierced his eyes.

events.title: Years of Suffering, Reunion, and Joyful Restoration
detailed_summary: The prince, now blind, wandered aimlessly through the forest for several years.
He subsisted on nothing but roots and berries, his existence consumed by lamentation and weeping over the loss of his dearest Rapunzel.
After years of miserable roaming, he eventually found himself in the desert where Rapunzel had been banished.
She was living in wretchedness with their twin children, a boy and a girl, to whom she had given birth.
He heard a voice that sounded deeply familiar and moved towards its source.
Upon his approach, Rapunzel recognized him.
She embraced him and wept on his neck.
Two of her tears fell upon his eyes, miraculously clearing them and restoring his sight to what it was before.
He then led Rapunzel and their children to his kingdom, where they received a joyful welcome.
They lived together for a long time thereafter, in happiness and contentment.

events.title: The Forester's Discovery and Fundevogel's Upbringing
detailed_summary: A forester, while engaged in hunting, was drawn by the sound of a child's screams emanating from the forest.
He discovered the child situated high up in a tree.
It was revealed that the child's mother had dozed off, allowing a bird of prey to seize the child from her arms and deposit it onto the tall tree.
The forester successfully retrieved the child from the tree.
He resolved to bring the child to his home, intending for the child to be raised alongside his own daughter, Lina.
The discovered child was given the name Fundevogel, a name reflecting that a bird had carried him.
Fundevogel and Lina cultivated a deep and loving bond, experiencing sadness whenever they were not in each other's presence.

events.text_segment:
There was once a forester who went into the forest to hunt, and as he entered it he heard a sound of screaming as if a little child were there. He followed the sound, and at last came to a high tree, and at the top of this a little child was sitting, for the mother had fallen asleep under the tree with the child, and a bird of prey had seen it in her arms, had flown down, snatched it away, and set it on the high tree.
The forester climbed up, brought the child down, and thought to himself: ‘You will take him home with you, and bring him up with your Lina.’ He took it home, therefore, and the two children grew up together. And the one, which he had found on a tree was called Fundevogel, because a bird had carried it away. Fundevogel and Lina loved each other so dearly that when they did not see each other they were sad.

He decided to take the child home and raise him with his own daughter, Lina. The child was named Fundevogel, for the bird had found him. Fundevogel and Lina grew up together and became very fond of each other, and they were always sad when they were not together.
