segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In his flight he had forgotten the most valuable things he had, the blue light and the gold, and had only one ducat in his pocket.

events.text_segment:
Next morning the king sent his people out to seek the track, but it was all in vain, for in every street poor children were sitting, picking up peas, and saying: ‘It must have rained peas, last night.’ ‘We must think of something else,’ said the king; ‘keep your shoes on when you go to bed, and before you come back from the place where you are taken, hide one of them there, I will soon contrive to find it.’ The black manikin heard this plot, and at night when the soldier again ordered him to bring the princess, revealed it to him, and told him that he knew of no expedient to counteract this stratagem, and that if the shoe were found in the soldier’s house it would go badly with him. ‘Do what I bid you,’ replied the soldier, and again this third night the princess was obliged to work like a servant, but before she went away, she hid her shoe under the bed.
Next morning the king had the entire town searched for his daughter’s shoe. It was found at the soldier’s, and the soldier himself, who at the entreaty of the dwarf had gone outside the gate, was soon brought back, and thrown into prison. In his flight he had forgotten the most valuable things he had, the blue light and the gold, and had only one ducat in his pocket.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Next morning the king sent his people out to seek the track, but it was all in vain, for in every street poor children were sitting, picking up peas, and saying: ‘It must have rained peas, last night.’

The king was greatly troubled, and at last he said to himself, ‘I must try another way.’ So he went to his daughter and said, ‘If you are really the right princess, you will be able to sleep in these slippers all night, and when you come back from wherever you are taken, you will leave one of them behind.’

The black dwarf heard this, and when the soldier came to take the princess away, he said to him, ‘I know no way to prevent this. If the shoe is found in your house, you are lost.’

But the soldier only laughed, and said, ‘Do as you are told.’

So the third night came, and the princess had to work as a servant again. Before she went, she left one of her slippers under the soldier’s bed.

Next morning the king had the whole town searched for the shoe. It was found in the soldier’s house, and the soldier, who had just stepped outside the gate at the dwarf’s advice, was caught and put in prison.

In his flight he had forgotten the blue light and the gold, and had only a single ducat in his pocket.

events.title: The Soldier's Final Plea, The Manikin's Intervention, and Ultimate Triumph
detailed_summary: Chained in his dungeon, the soldier saw a former comrade pass by his window.
He tapped on the glass, and when the man approached, the soldier asked him to fetch a small bundle he had left at the inn, offering a ducat for this service.
His comrade retrieved the bundle and brought it to him.
Once alone, the soldier lit his pipe with the blue light, summoning the black manikin.
The manikin told his master not to fear, to go wherever they took him, and to ensure he had the blue light with him.
The next day, the soldier was tried and, despite having done nothing wicked in the conventional sense, was condemned to death by the judge.
As he was led to his execution, he begged a last favor from the king: to be allowed to smoke one more pipe on his way.
The king granted him permission to smoke three pipes but stated this would not spare his life.
The soldier pulled out his pipe, lit it at the blue light, and as smoke wreaths ascended, the manikin appeared with a small cudgel, asking for commands.
The soldier ordered him to strike down the false judge, his constable, and not to spare the king who had treated him so poorly.
The manikin attacked like lightning, felling anyone touched by his cudgel, rendering them unable to move.
Terrified, the king threw himself on the soldier's mercy and, to be allowed to live, gave the soldier his kingdom and his daughter in marriage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And now loaded with chains, he was standing at the window of his dungeon, when he chanced to see one of his comrades passing by.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The king was terrified; he threw himself on the soldier’s mercy, and merely to be allowed to live at all, gave him his kingdom for his own, and his daughter to wife.

events.text_segment: And now loaded with chains, he was standing at the window of his dungeon, when he chanced to see one of his comrades passing by. The soldier tapped at the pane of glass, and when this man came up, said to him: ‘Be so kind as to fetch me the small bundle I have left lying in the inn, and I will give you a ducat for doing it.’ His comrade ran thither and brought him what he wanted. As soon as the soldier was alone again, he lighted his pipe and summoned the black manikin. ‘Have no fear,’ said the latter to his master. ‘Go wheresoever they take you, and let them do what they will, only take the blue light with you.’ Next day the soldier was tried, and though he had done nothing wicked, the judge condemned him to death. When he was led forth to die, he begged a last favour of the king. ‘What is it?’ asked the king. ‘That I may smoke one more pipe on my way.’ ‘You may smoke three,’ answered the king, ‘but do not imagine that I will spare your life.’ Then the soldier pulled out his pipe and lighted it at the blue light, and as soon as a few wreaths of smoke had ascended, the manikin was there with a small cudgel in his hand, and said: ‘What does my lord command?’ ‘Strike down to earth that false judge there, and his constable, and spare not the king who has treated me so ill.’ Then the manikin fell on them like lightning, darting this way and that way, and whosoever was so much as touched by his cudgel fell to earth, and did not venture to stir again. The king was terrified; he threw himself on the soldier’s mercy, and merely to be allowed to live at all, gave him his kingdom for his own, and his daughter to wife.

One night, when the guards were not looking, he managed to break free from his chains and ran into the forest. He found the old woman's house and knocked on the door. The old woman was surprised to see a man in chains, but she welcomed him in and gave him food and drink. Then she asked him why he had come. He told her his story, and she listened carefully. After a while, she said, "I can help you, but you must do as I say." The old woman gave him a magic cloak that made him invisible. She told him to use it to return to the castle and free his comrades. The prisoner was grateful and set off at once. When he reached the castle, he used the cloak to slip past the guards and into the dungeon. He found his comrades and set them free. Together, they made their way out of the castle and into the forest. They were safe at last, and they thanked the old woman for her help. From that day on, they were never separated again, and they lived happily ever after.

events.title: The Queen's Impatient Wish and the Daughter's Transformation
detailed_summary: A queen possessed a young daughter who was behaving quite fretfully one day.
The mother, struggling to calm her child and growing exasperated, observed ravens circling the castle.
In a moment of frustration, she uttered a wish for her daughter to become a raven and fly away, simply so she could have some tranquility.
Her words had an immediate and magical effect: the child she held transformed into a raven.
The newly transformed raven-daughter then flew out through the open window, vanishing into a dense, dark forest.
For a significant period afterward, the parents received no news or sighting of their lost child.

events.text_segment: There was once a queen who had a little daughter, still too young to run alone. One day the child was very troublesome, and the mother could not quiet it, do what she would. She grew impatient, and seeing the ravens flying round the castle, she opened the window, and said: ‘I wish you were a raven and would fly away, then I should have a little peace.’ Scarcely were the words out of her mouth, when the child in her arms was turned into a raven, and flew away from her through the open window. The bird took its flight to a dark wood and remained there for a long time, and meanwhile the parents could hear nothing of their child.

events.title: The Enchanted Princess's Plea and Instructions for Rescue
detailed_summary: A long time later, a man traversing the forest heard a raven's call and decided to follow the sound.
Upon reaching the raven, she disclosed her true identity as a king's daughter, currently under an enchantment, and explained that he possessed the ability to free her.
When the man inquired about the method, she directed him to proceed further into the woods until he located a house inhabited by an elderly woman.

She cautioned that the old woman would present him with food and drink, but he must abstain from consuming either, as doing so would cause him to fall into a profound sleep, rendering him incapable of assisting her.
His task was to find a large tan-heap situated in the garden behind the house, stand upon it, and await her arrival.

The princess specified she would arrive in her carriage at two o'clock in the afternoon on three consecutive days: the first day with four white horses, the second with four chestnut horses, and the third with four black horses.
She sternly warned that if he failed to remain awake and she found him asleep, her freedom would not be secured.
The man pledged to carry out all her instructions.
Despite his promise, the raven voiced her premonition that he would inevitably accept something from the old woman and thus be unable to save her.
The man reiterated his assurance that he would absolutely not touch any food or drink.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The man assured her again that he would on no account touch a thing to eat or drink.

events.text_segment:
Long after this, a man was making his way through the wood when he heard a raven calling, and he followed the sound of the voice. As he drew near, the raven said, ‘I am by birth a king’s daughter, but am now under the spell of some enchantment; you can, however, set me free.’ ‘What am I to do?’ he asked. She replied, ‘Go farther into the wood until you come to a house, wherein lives an old woman; she will offer you food and drink, but you must not take of either; if you do, you will fall into a deep sleep, and will not be able to help me. In the garden behind the house is a large tan-heap, and on that you must stand and watch for me. I shall drive there in my carriage at two o’clock in the afternoon for three successive days; the first day it will be drawn by four white, the second by four chestnut, and the last by four black horses; but if you fail to keep awake and I find you sleeping, I shall not be set free.’
The man promised to do all that she wished, but the raven said, ‘Alas! I know even now that you will take something from the woman and be unable to save me.’ The man assured her again that he would on no account touch a thing to eat or drink.

The old woman looked up and said, “I have lost my way in this world, and no one will help me.” The raven spoke up, “She is a witch who once had great power, but she has lost her magic and now lives in sorrow.” Moved by pity, the man offered to help her. The witch, surprised, asked, “What can you do?” “I will stay with you,” he said, “and help you find your way again.” The witch was overjoyed and offered him a reward. “Then take this ring,” she said, “it will grant you one wish.” The man thanked her and continued on his journey. Some time later, he found himself in a village where a cruel king ruled. The people were suffering, and the man decided to use his wish to free them. He wished for the king to be overthrown and justice to be restored. The wish came true, and the people rejoiced. The man, now a hero, returned to the witch to thank her. She smiled and said, “You have done well. Your kindness has brought light to the world.” And with that, the raven flew away, and the man walked on, his heart full of joy.

events.title: The First Temptation and Failure at the Tan-Heap
detailed_summary: Upon arriving at the designated house and entering, the man was met by the old woman, who commented on his apparent exhaustion and invited him to rest and accept some food and drink.
The man initially declined her offer, stating his intention to neither eat nor drink.
The old woman, however, was persistent, suggesting that even if he chose not to eat, a mere sip of wine would be inconsequential.
Eventually, the man allowed himself to be convinced and consumed the wine.
As the prearranged time of two o'clock neared, he proceeded to the garden and positioned himself atop the tan-heap to await the raven princess.

An unexpected and overwhelming sensation of fatigue washed over him, and despite his firm resolution to stay awake, he succumbed, lay down, and fell into a sleep so deep that no noise could rouse him.
At two o'clock, the raven princess arrived, her carriage drawn by four white horses.
Even before reaching the tan-heap, she sighed, expressing her sorrowful certainty that he had fallen asleep.
Upon entering the garden, she discovered him, as she had feared, lying on the tan-heap in a deep slumber.
She disembarked from her carriage, approached him, called his name, and shook him, but all her efforts were futile; he remained asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When he came to the house and went inside, the old woman met him, and said, ‘Poor man! how tired you are! Come in and rest and let me give you something to eat and drink.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She got out of her carriage and went to him; she called him and shook him, but it was all in vain, he still continued sleeping.

events.text_segment:
When he came to the house and went inside, the old woman met him, and said, ‘Poor man! how tired you are! Come in and rest and let me give you something to eat and drink.’
‘No,’ answered the man, ‘I will neither eat not drink.’
But she would not leave him alone, and urged him saying, ‘If you will not eat anything, at least you might take a draught of wine; one drink counts for nothing,’ and at last he allowed himself to be persuaded, and drank.
As it drew towards the appointed hour, he went outside into the garden and mounted the tan-heap to await the raven. Suddenly a feeling of fatigue came over him, and unable to resist it, he lay down for a little while, fully determined, however, to keep awake; but in another minute his eyes closed of their own accord, and he fell into such a deep sleep, that all the noises in the world would not have awakened him. At two o’clock the raven came driving along, drawn by her four white horses; but even before she reached the spot, she said to herself, sighing, ‘I know he has fallen asleep.’ When she entered the garden, there she found him as she had feared, lying on the tan-heap, fast asleep. She got out of her carriage and went to him; she called him and shook him, but it was all in vain, he still continued sleeping.

When the raven princess drove up with her four chestnut horses, she said to herself sorrowfully, already knowing that he would be asleep. She went to find him, as she had done the day before, but he was sleeping so soundly that she could not wake him.

events.title: The Final Failure, the Raven's Gifts, and New Instructions
detailed_summary: On the third day, the old woman questioned the man's complete abstinence from food and drink, asking if he intended to cause his own demise.
He responded that he was forbidden and unwilling to either eat or drink.
Despite his refusal, she placed a dish of food and a glass of wine before him. The aroma of the wine proved too enticing, and he yielded to the temptation, taking a substantial drink.
When the appointed hour arrived again, he went to the tan-heap in the garden to await the king's daughter, but he felt an even greater weariness than on the preceding two days.
He collapsed onto the heap and slept as soundly as a log.
At two o'clock, the raven princess approached; this time, her coachman, her attire, and her horses were all black.
She appeared more sorrowful than ever as she drove, mournfully acknowledging that he was asleep and would be unable to free her.
She found him deeply asleep, and all her attempts to rouse him were unsuccessful.
Before departing, she placed beside him a loaf of bread, a portion of meat, and a flask of wine, all possessing the magical quality of never diminishing, no matter how much was consumed.
She then removed a gold ring, engraved with her name, from her finger and placed it onto one of his.
Finally, she left a letter near him, detailing the inexhaustible nature of the provisions and concluding with the message that he would never be able to free her as long as he remained there.
The letter further instructed that if he still wished to rescue her, he should journey to the golden castle of Stromberg, an endeavor she stated was well within his capability to achieve.
With these actions completed, she returned to her carriage and drove towards the golden castle of Stromberg.

events.text_segment:
The following day the old woman said to him, ‘What is this? You are not eating or drinking anything, do you want to kill yourself?’
He answered, ‘I may not and will not either eat or drink.’
But she put down the dish of food and the glass of wine in front of him, and when he smelt the wine, he was unable to resist the temptation, and took a deep draught.
When the hour came round again he went as usual on to the tan-heap in the garden to await the king’s daughter, but he felt even more overcome with weariness than on the two previous days, and throwing himself down, he slept like a log. At two o’clock the raven could be seen approaching, and this time her coachman and everything about her, as well as her horses, were black.
She was sadder than ever as she drove along, and said mournfully, ‘I know he has fallen asleep, and will not be able to set me free.’ She found him sleeping heavily, and all her efforts to awaken him were of no avail. Then she placed beside him a loaf, and some meat, and a flask of wine, of such a kind, that however much he took of them, they would never grow less. After that she drew a gold ring, on which her name was engraved, off her finger, and put it upon one of his. Finally, she laid a letter near him, in which, after giving him particulars of the food and drink she had left for him, she finished with the following words: ‘I see that as long as you remain here you will never be able to set me free; if, however, you still wish to do so, come to the golden castle of Stromberg; this is well within your power to accomplish.’ She then returned to her carriage and drove to the golden castle of Stromberg.

events.title: The Man's Renewed Quest and Encounter with a Hungry Giant
detailed_summary: Upon awakening and realizing he had slept through the princess's visit yet again, the man was deeply distressed, lamenting that she had likely departed and that his chance to save her was lost.
His attention was then drawn to the items lying beside him; he read the letter and fully understood the events that had transpired.
He rose immediately, eager to begin his journey to the castle of Stromberg, though he was entirely unsure of which direction to take.
He wandered for a considerable time in search of it and eventually found himself in a dark forest, through which he walked for fourteen days without discovering an exit.
As night fell once more, exhausted, he lay down beneath a bush and fell asleep.
The next day he continued his journey through the forest, and that evening, intending to rest, he lay down again but was kept awake by terrifying howling and wailing sounds.
He waited until the surroundings grew darker and people began to illuminate their homes, then noticed a faint glimmer of light in the distance and moved towards it.
He discovered the light emanated from a house that seemed smaller than its actual size due to the presence of an enormous giant standing before it.
The man initially feared for his life, thinking the giant would surely harm him if seen, but eventually mustered his courage and approached.
When the giant spotted him, he declared the man's arrival opportune, as he hadn't eaten for a long time and planned to make the man his supper.
The man protested, stating he did not wish to be eaten and offered to satisfy the giant's hunger with the ample provisions he carried.
The giant, upon hearing this offer, agreed to spare him, explaining his intention to eat the man stemmed only from a lack of alternative food.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the man awoke and found that he had been sleeping, he was grieved at heart, and said, ‘She has no doubt been here and driven away again, and it is now too late for me to save her.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘I only thought of eating you because I had nothing else.’

events.text_segment:
When the man awoke and found that he had been sleeping, he was grieved at heart, and said, ‘She has no doubt been here and driven away again, and it is now too late for me to save her.’ Then his eyes fell on the things which were lying beside him; he read the letter, and knew from it all that had happened. He rose up without delay, eager to start on his way and to reach the castle of Stromberg, but he had no idea in which direction he ought to go. He travelled about a long time in search of it and came at last to a dark forest, through which he went on walking for fourteen days and still could not find a way out. Once more the night came on, and worn out he lay down under a bush and fell asleep. Again the next day he pursued his way through the forest, and that evening, thinking to rest again, he lay down as before, but he heard such a howling and wailing that he found it impossible to sleep. He waited till it was darker and people had begun to light up their houses, and then seeing a little glimmer ahead of him, he went towards it.
He found that the light came from a house which looked smaller than it really was, from the contrast of its height with that of an immense giant who stood in front of it. He thought to himself, ‘If the giant sees me going in, my life will not be worth much.’ However, after a while he summoned up courage and went forward. When the giant saw him, he called out, ‘It is lucky for that you have come, for I have not had anything to eat for a long time. I can have you now for my supper.’ ‘I would rather you let that alone,’ said the man, ‘for I do not willingly give myself up to be eaten; if you are wanting food I have enough to satisfy your hunger.’ ‘If that is so,’ replied the giant, ‘I will leave you in peace; I only thought of eating you because I had nothing else.’

events.title: Giants' Assistance in Locating Stromberg Castle
detailed_summary: The man and the giant entered the house together and sat down. The man then brought out his magical bread, meat, and wine, which remained undiminished despite his previous consumption.
The giant was delighted with the meal and ate and drank heartily.
After the giant had finished his supper, the man asked if he could provide directions to the castle of Stromberg.
The giant offered to consult his map, claiming it contained markings for all towns, villages, and houses.
He retrieved his map but was unable to locate the castle.
Unfazed, the giant mentioned having larger maps stored upstairs in a cupboard and suggested they look at those, but their search on these larger maps also proved futile; the castle was not marked.
The man was about to continue his journey, but the giant persuaded him to stay for another day or two, awaiting the return of his brother, who was currently away searching for provisions.
When the brother arrived home, they inquired about the castle of Stromberg. He informed them he would look at his own maps as soon as he had eaten and satisfied his hunger.
Accordingly, after he finished his meal, they all proceeded to his room and examined his maps, but the castle was still not found.
The brother then fetched other, older maps, and they continued their search until, at long last, they located the castle, though it was noted to be many thousands of miles away.
The man questioned how he could possibly travel such a vast distance.
The giant's brother stated he had two hours available and offered to transport the man to the vicinity of the castle, explaining he then needed to return to care for a child under their protection.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘I must then return to look after the child who is in our care.’

The giant said, ‘I will look on my map; on it are marked all the towns, villages, and houses.’ So he fetched his map, and looked for the castle, but could not find it. ‘Never mind,’ he said, ‘I have larger maps upstairs in the cupboard, we will look on those,’ but they searched in vain, for the castle was not marked even on these. The man now thought he should like to continue his journey, but the giant begged him to remain for a day or two longer until the return of his brother, who was away in search of provisions. When the brother came home, they asked him about the castle of Stromberg, and he told them he would look on his own maps as soon as he had eaten and appeased his hunger. Accordingly, when he had finished his supper, they all went up together to his room and looked through his maps, but the castle was not to be found. Then he fetched other older maps, and they went on looking for the castle until at last they found it, but it was many thousand miles away. ‘How shall I be able to get there?’ asked the man. ‘I have two hours to spare,’ said the giant, ‘and I will carry you into the neighbourhood of the castle; I must then return to look after the child who is in our care.’

events.title: Arrival at the Glass Mountain and a Year of Frustrated Vigil
detailed_summary: The giant then transported the man to a location approximately one hundred leagues from the castle.
He left the man there, informing him that he would be able to walk the remaining distance on his own.
The man journeyed relentlessly, day and night, until he finally arrived at the golden castle of Stromberg.
He discovered that the castle was perched atop a mountain made of glass.
Looking up from the base of the mountain, he saw the enchanted princess driving her carriage around the castle before disappearing inside.
He was ecstatic to see her and desperately wanted to reach the summit, but the slopes of the glass mountain were exceedingly slippery, causing him to fall back with every attempt to climb.
Recognizing the impossibility of reaching her by climbing, he was overcome with sorrow and resolved to remain there and wait for her.
To this end, he constructed a small hut for himself and stayed there, watching, for an entire year.
Every day, he witnessed the king's daughter driving around her castle, yet he remained unable to get any closer to her.

events.title: Encounter with Robbers and Acquisition of Magical Items
detailed_summary: One day, observing from his hut, the man noticed three robbers engaged in a physical altercation and called out a greeting to them.
They momentarily ceased their fighting upon hearing the call, but after looking around and seeing no one, they resumed their conflict with increased ferocity.
He called out his greeting a second time; they paused again, scanned their surroundings, but seeing no one, returned to their struggle.
He called out a third time, and then, driven by a desire to understand the cause of their dispute, he approached them and inquired why they were fighting with such anger.
One robber revealed he had found a stick that, when struck against any door, would cause it to fly open immediately.
Another robber explained he had discovered a cloak that rendered its wearer invisible.
The third robber had captured a horse capable of carrying its rider over any obstacle, including the glass mountain.
Their disagreement stemmed from being unable to decide whether to remain together and share these items or to separate.

Upon hearing this, the man proposed an exchange: he would give them something of far greater value than money (which he lacked) for their three items, but first, he needed to verify if their claims about the items were true.
The robbers agreed, allowing him to mount the horse and handing him the stick and the cloak. As soon as he put on the cloak, he vanished from their sight.
He then used the stick to attack them, striking them one after another, and mockingly declared that they, as idle vagabonds, had received their just deserts and asked if they were now satisfied.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Looking out from his hut one day he saw three robbers fighting and he called out to them, ‘God be with you.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘There, you idle vagabonds, you have got what you deserve; are you satisfied now!’

events.text_segment: Looking out from his hut one day he saw three robbers fighting and he called out to them, ‘God be with you.’ They stopped when they heard the call, but looking round and seeing nobody, they went on again with their fighting, which now became more furious. ‘God be with you,’ he cried again, and again they paused and looked about, but seeing no one went back to their fighting. A third time he called out, ‘God be with you,’ and then thinking he should like to know the cause of dispute between the three men, he went out and asked them why they were fighting so angrily with one another. One of them said that he had found a stick, and that he had but to strike it against any door through which he wished to pass, and it immediately flew open. Another told him that he had found a cloak which rendered its wearer invisible; and the third had caught a horse which would carry its rider over any obstacle, and even up the glass mountain. They had been unable to decide whether they would keep together and have the things in common, or whether they would separate. On hearing this, the man said, ‘I will give you something in exchange for those three things; not money, for that I have not got, but something that is of far more value. I must first, however, prove whether all you have told me about your three things is true.’ The robbers, therefore, made him get on the horse, and handed him the stick and the cloak, and when he had put this round him he was no longer visible. Then he fell upon them with the stick and beat them one after another, crying, ‘There, you idle vagabonds, you have got what you deserve; are you satisfied now!’

He called out a third time, and then, because he was curious to know what they were fighting about, he went up to them and asked them why they were so angry. The third said he had caught a horse that could carry a man over any obstacle, even the glass mountain. They could not agree whether to stay together and share these things or to go their separate ways. Then the man said he would give them something better than money for the three things, but first he must try them. The robbers agreed, and gave him the stick and the cloak, and let him mount the horse. When he put on the cloak, he vanished from their sight. events.title: The Princess Rescued and Joyful Reunion at Stromberg Castle
detailed_summary: Following this acquisition, the man rode the magical horse up the slippery slopes of the glass mountain.
Upon reaching the castle gate, he found it closed, but with a single blow from his magical stick, the gate immediately flew wide open, granting him passage.
He proceeded up the steps and entered the chamber where the princess was seated, a golden goblet filled with wine placed before her.
She was unable to see him because he was still enveloped in the invisibility cloak.
He then took the ring she had previously given him off his finger and dropped it into her goblet, creating a distinct sound as it settled at the bottom.
The princess exclaimed that it was her own ring and, from this, deduced that the man destined to free her must be present in the room.
She began to search the castle for him but was unable to locate him anywhere.
In the meantime, the man had exited the room, remounted his horse, and removed the invisibility cloak.
Consequently, when the princess arrived at the castle gate, she saw him standing there and cried out loud with immense joy.
He then dismounted from the horse and took her into his arms.
She kissed him and joyfully declared that he had now truly set her free, and they would proceed to celebrate their marriage on the very next day.

events.text_segment:
After this he rode up the glass mountain. When he reached the gate of the castle, he found it closed, but he gave it a blow with his stick, and it flew wide open at once and he passed through. He mounted the steps and entered the room where the maiden was sitting, with a golden goblet full of wine in front of her. She could not see him for he still wore his cloak. He took the ring which she had given him off his finger, and threw it into the goblet, so that it rang as it touched the bottom. ‘That is my own ring,’ she exclaimed, ‘and if that is so the man must also be here who is coming to set me free.’
She sought for him about the castle, but could find him nowhere. Meanwhile he had gone outside again and mounted his horse and thrown off the cloak. When therefore she came to the castle gate she saw him, and cried aloud for joy. Then he dismounted and took her in his arms; and she kissed him, and said, ‘Now you have indeed set me free, and tomorrow we will celebrate our marriage.’

events.title: The Elder Brothers' Selfishness and Misfortune
detailed_summary: The narrative introduces a man with three sons, the youngest named Dummling, who is consistently looked down upon.
The eldest son prepared to go into the forest to cut wood, equipped by his mother with a fine cake and wine to prevent hunger and thirst.
In the forest, he encountered a small, elderly grey-haired man who asked for some food and drink due to his own hunger and thirst.
The eldest son, described as clever, selfishly refused, stating he would have none left for himself, and continued on his way, leaving the old man.

While attempting to chop down a tree, the eldest son quickly made an errant swing with his axe, injuring his arm and forcing him to return home for medical attention. This misfortune was attributed to the little grey man's influence.
Subsequently, the second son ventured into the forest, similarly provisioned by his mother with cake and wine.
He too met the little old grey man, who made the same request for a piece of cake and a drink of wine.
The second son also rationally declined, reasoning that sharing would leave him with nothing, and went on, leaving the old man.
His retribution followed swiftly; after a few swings at a tree, he struck his own leg and had to be transported back home.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a man who had three sons, the youngest of whom was called Dummling,[*] and was despised, mocked, and sneered at on every occasion.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His punishment, however, was not delayed; when he had made a few blows at the tree he struck himself in the leg, so that he had to be carried home.

events.text_segment:
There was a man who had three sons, the youngest of whom was called Dummling,[*] and was despised, mocked, and sneered at on every occasion.
It happened that the eldest wanted to go into the forest to hew wood, and before he went his mother gave him a beautiful sweet cake and a bottle of wine in order that he might not suffer from hunger or thirst.
When he entered the forest he met a little grey-haired old man who bade him good day, and said: ‘Do give me a piece of cake out of your pocket, and let me have a draught of your wine; I am so hungry and thirsty.’ But the clever son answered: ‘If I give you my cake and wine, I shall have none for myself; be off with you,’ and he left the little man standing and went on.
But when he began to hew down a tree, it was not long before he made a false stroke, and the axe cut him in the arm, so that he had to go home and have it bound up. And this was the little grey man’s doing.
After this the second son went into the forest, and his mother gave him, like the eldest, a cake and a bottle of wine. The little old grey man met him likewise, and asked him for a piece of cake and a drink of wine. But the second son, too, said sensibly enough: ‘What I give you will be taken away from myself; be off!’ and he left the little man standing and went on. His punishment, however, was not delayed; when he had made a few blows at the tree he struck himself in the leg, so that he had to be carried home.

Soon after, as he was trying to fell a tree, he gave a careless swing with his axe and cut off his own arm. He had to go home and let the wound be dressed, and people said it was the little grey man's doing. The second son then went into the forest, and his mother gave him a cake and a bottle of wine, just as she had given to his brother. He also met the little grey-haired old man, who asked for a piece of cake and a drink of wine. The second son said, "If I give you any, I shall have none left for myself," and went on. But as he was cutting down a tree, he gave a few blows and then struck his own leg, and had to be carried home. Then it was the turn of Dummling, the youngest son, who was always laughed at and made fun of. His mother gave him a piece of black bread and a bottle of water, and said, "Be sure to take these with you, so that you may not be hungry or thirsty." When he was in the forest, he met the little grey-haired old man, who asked for a piece of black bread and a drink of water. Dummling said, "Sit down and eat with me; we shall both be the better for it." So the old man sat down and they shared the food. Then the old man said, "Since you are so kind, I will give you a reward. When you go home, you will find a golden goose in the stable. Take care of it, and it will bring you good fortune."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: There was a man who had three sons, the youngest of whom was called Dummling,[*] and was despised, mocked, and sneered at on every occasion. The two older brothers were proud and ambitious, always seeking to outdo each other in their plans and dreams. Dummling, however, was quiet and unassuming, content with simple pleasures and the company of his mother, who alone treated him kindly. One day, the king announced a grand tournament, offering his daughter’s hand in marriage to the man who could perform the most extraordinary feat. The two older brothers were overjoyed and immediately set off to prepare for the contest. Dummling, too, was invited, but he hesitated, unsure of his abilities. His mother, sensing his fear, gave him a small wooden spoon and said, “Take this with you, and it will help you in your time of need.” With a heavy heart, Dummling set off on his journey. Along the way, he met a poor old woman who asked for food. Without hesitation, Dummling gave her the last of his provisions. The old woman, grateful, gave him a magical cloak that would make him invisible. Encouraged by this gift, Dummling continued on his way, eventually arriving at the tournament. There, he witnessed the two older brothers performing impressive feats, but none as remarkable as the simple kindness and humility Dummling had shown. The king, impressed by Dummling’s heart and the help of his magical cloak, declared him the winner and offered his daughter’s hand in marriage. Thus, the once-mocked Dummling became a prince, proving that true greatness lies not in strength or ambition, but in kindness and humility.

events.title: Dummling's Kindness and Magical Reward
detailed_summary: Dummling then requested his father's permission to go and cut wood.

His father initially dismissed the idea, citing the injuries his brothers sustained and Dummling's perceived lack of skill, but eventually relented after Dummling's persistent pleading, suggesting he might learn from his own mistakes.
His mother provided him with a meager cake made with water and baked in cinders, along with a bottle of sour beer.
Upon entering the forest, Dummling also encountered the little old grey man, who greeted him and requested a piece of his cake and a drink from his bottle due to hunger and thirst.
Dummling responded humbly, offering his cinder-cake and sour beer, and invited the old man to sit and eat with him if he found it acceptable.
As they sat down and Dummling took out his provisions, the cinder-cake transformed into a fine sweet cake, and the sour beer became good wine.
They ate and drank together, after which the little man, acknowledging Dummling's good heart and willingness to share, promised him good luck.
He instructed Dummling to cut down a nearby old tree, telling him he would find something valuable at its roots.
The little man then departed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Dummling said: ‘Father, do let me go and cut wood.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the little man took leave of him.

events.text_segment:
Then Dummling said: ‘Father, do let me go and cut wood.’ The father answered: ‘Your brothers have hurt themselves with it, leave it alone, you do not understand anything about it.’ But Dummling begged so long that at last he said: ‘Just go then, you will get wiser by hurting yourself.’ His mother gave him a cake made with water and baked in the cinders, and with it a bottle of sour beer.
When he came to the forest the little old grey man met him likewise, and greeting him, said: ‘Give me a piece of your cake and a drink out of your bottle; I am so hungry and thirsty.’ Dummling answered: ‘I have only cinder-cake and sour beer; if that pleases you, we will sit down and eat.’ So they sat down, and when Dummling pulled out his cinder-cake, it was a fine sweet cake, and the sour beer had become good wine. So they ate and drank, and after that the little man said: ‘Since you have a good heart, and are willing to divide what you have, I will give you good luck. There stands an old tree, cut it down, and you will find something at the roots.’ Then the little man took leave of him.

His father laughed and said, 'What, Dummling, wilt thou go and cut wood? Thou art too simple for that. My eldest son had his hand cut off, and the second his foot, and the third his eye, and the fourth his ear, and the fifth his nose, and the sixth his lip, and the seventh his chin, and the eighth his cheek, and the ninth his jaw, and the tenth his tongue, and the eleventh his teeth, and the twelfth his throat, and the thirteenth his neck, and the fourteenth his shoulder, and the fifteenth his arm, and the sixteenth his leg, and the seventeenth his knee, and the eighteenth his heel, and the nineteenth his toe, and the twentieth his ankle, and the twenty-first his hip, and the twenty-second his back, and the twenty-third his breast, and the twenty-fourth his belly, and the twenty-fifth his side, and the twenty-sixth his ribs, and the twenty-seventh his heart, and the twenty-eighth his liver, and the twenty-ninth his lungs, and the thirtieth his brain, and the thirty-first his soul. And if thou goest, thou wilt lose something too.'

But Dummling said, 'Let me go, father, I will try.'

So his father said, 'Go then, and may the Lord help thee.'

Then his mother gave him a cake made with water and baked in cinders, and a bottle of sour beer, and said, 'Thou art a simpleton, but go, and may the Lord help thee.'

Then Dummling went into the forest, and when he had gone a little way, he met a little old grey man, who said, 'Good day, good day, good Dummling. I am hungry and thirsty. Wilt thou give me a piece of thy cake and a drink of thy beer?'

Dummling said, 'With all my heart, good man. Sit down and eat with me.'

So they sat down, and Dummling took out his cake and his beer. But when he gave the old man a piece of the cake, it was a fine sweet cake, and when he gave him a drink of the beer, it was good wine.

Then the old man said, 'Thou art a good-hearted lad, and I will give thee good luck. Cut down that old tree yonder, and at its roots thou wilt find something good.'

Then the old man went away, and Dummling cut down the tree, and at its roots he found a golden goose.

events.title: The Golden Goose and the Stuck Innkeeper's Daughters
detailed_summary: Dummling proceeded to cut down the indicated tree.
When the tree fell, he discovered a goose with feathers of pure gold sitting among its roots.
He picked up the golden goose and carried it with him to an inn, intending to stay there for the night.
The innkeeper had three daughters who observed the goose and were intrigued by such a marvelous bird, each wishing to obtain one of its golden feathers.

The eldest daughter planned to seize an opportunity to pluck a feather. When Dummling briefly left the room, she grabbed the goose by its wing, only to find her finger and hand inexplicably stuck fast to it.
Shortly thereafter, the second daughter approached, also aiming to get a feather for herself. However, as soon as she touched her sister, she too became stuck fast.

Finally, the third daughter came with the same intention. Despite her sisters' cries to stay away, she didn't understand the reason and, thinking she might as well join them, ran towards them. Upon touching her sister, she also remained firmly stuck.
Consequently, the three daughters were forced to spend the entire night attached to the goose.

events.text_segment:
Dummling went and cut down the tree, and when it fell there was a goose sitting in the roots with feathers of pure gold. He lifted her up, and taking her with him, went to an inn where he thought he would stay the night. Now the host had three daughters, who saw the goose and were curious to know what such a wonderful bird might be, and would have liked to have one of its golden feathers.
The eldest thought: ‘I shall soon find an opportunity of pulling out a feather,’ and as soon as Dummling had gone out she seized the goose by the wing, but her finger and hand remained sticking fast to it.
The second came soon afterwards, thinking only of how she might get a feather for herself, but she had scarcely touched her sister than she was held fast.
At last the third also came with the like intent, and the others screamed out: ‘Keep away; for goodness’ sake keep away!’ But she did not understand why she was to keep away. ‘The others are there,’ she thought, ‘I may as well be there too,’ and ran to them; but as soon as she had touched her sister, she remained sticking fast to her. So they had to spend the night with the goose.

events.title: The Growing Procession Adheres to Dummling
detailed_summary: The following morning, Dummling took the goose under his arm and departed, paying no mind to the three girls who were still attached to it.
The girls were compelled to run after him continuously, following him left and right, wherever his journey led.
In the middle of some fields, they encountered a parson. Seeing the procession, he admonished the girls for unseemly behavior, questioning why they were chasing the young man across the fields.
Attempting to pull the youngest girl away, the parson seized her hand, but as soon as he touched her, he too became stuck fast and was forced to run behind in the procession.

Not long after, the sexton came by and saw his master, the parson, trailing behind three girls. Astonished, the sexton called out, asking the parson about his hasty departure and reminding him of a christening scheduled for that day.
The sexton ran after the parson and took him by the sleeve, only to become stuck fast himself.
While these five were trotting along one after another, two labourers with hoes approached from the fields. The parson shouted to them, begging them to free him and the sexton.
However, as soon as the labourers touched the sexton, they too were held fast, increasing the number of people running behind Dummling and the goose to seven.

events.text_segment:
The next morning Dummling took the goose under his arm and set out, without troubling himself about the three girls who were hanging on to it. They were obliged to run after him continually, now left, now right, wherever his legs took him.
In the middle of the fields the parson met them, and when he saw the procession he said: ‘For shame, you good-for-nothing girls, why are you running across the fields after this young man? Is that seemly?’ At the same time he seized the youngest by the hand in order to pull her away, but as soon as he touched her he likewise stuck fast, and was himself obliged to run behind.
Before long the sexton came by and saw his master, the parson, running behind three girls. He was astonished at this and called out: ‘Hi! your reverence, whither away so quickly? Do not forget that we have a christening today!’ and running after him he took him by the sleeve, but was also held fast to it.
Whilst the five were trotting thus one behind the other, two labourers came with their hoes from the fields; the parson called out to them and begged that they would set him and the sexton free. But they had scarcely touched the sexton when they were held fast, and now there were seven of them running behind Dummling and the goose.

events.title: Making the Princess Laugh and the First Royal Task Initiated
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, Dummling arrived in a city ruled by a king whose daughter was so perpetually serious that no one could make her laugh.
The king had issued a decree stating that whoever could make his daughter laugh would be permitted to marry her.
When Dummling learned of this, he went with his goose and its entire train of seven followers before the king's daughter.
As soon as the princess saw the seven people continuously running one behind the other, she began to laugh uproariously, as if she would never cease.
Following this, Dummling requested her hand in marriage.

However, the king was not pleased with the prospect of Dummling as a son-in-law and made various excuses, stipulating that Dummling must first produce a man capable of drinking an entire cellarful of wine.

Dummling thought of the little grey man, believing he could assist him. He went into the forest and, at the same spot where he had felled the tree, he saw a man sitting with a very sorrowful expression.

Dummling inquired what was causing him such distress, and the man replied that he suffered from an immense thirst that he couldn't quench, explaining that cold water was unbearable and that he had just emptied a barrel of wine, which felt like a mere drop on a hot stone to him.
Dummling declared he could help and invited the man to accompany him to be satisfied.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Soon afterwards he came to a city, where a king ruled who had a daughter who was so serious that no one could make her laugh.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘There, I can help you,’ said Dummling, ‘just come with me and you shall be satisfied.’

events.text_segment:
Soon afterwards he came to a city, where a king ruled who had a daughter who was so serious that no one could make her laugh. So he had put forth a decree that whosoever should be able to make her laugh should marry her. When Dummling heard this, he went with his goose and all her train before the king’s daughter, and as soon as she saw the seven people running on and on, one behind the other, she began to laugh quite loudly, and as if she would never stop. Thereupon Dummling asked to have her for his wife; but the king did not like the son-in-law, and made all manner of excuses and said he must first produce a man who could drink a cellarful of wine. Dummling thought of the little grey man, who could certainly help him; so he went into the forest, and in the same place where he had felled the tree, he saw a man sitting, who had a very sorrowful face. Dummling asked him what he was taking to heart so sorely, and he answered: ‘I have such a great thirst and cannot quench it; cold water I cannot stand, a barrel of wine I have just emptied, but that to me is like a drop on a hot stone!’
‘There, I can help you,’ said Dummling, ‘just come with me and you shall be satisfied.’

The princess, seated in her chamber, was known for her solemn demeanor, and the court was filled with the echoes of failed attempts to bring a smile to her face.

The king, desperate to find a suitor who could bring joy to his daughter, had issued a royal decree: *Whoever could make the princess laugh would be granted her hand in marriage.* Dummling, hearing of this, brought the goose and its followers before the princess. As the seven figures ran in a line behind the goose, the princess could not contain herself—she burst into laughter, a sound so joyous and unrestrained that it echoed through the palace halls.

Delighted by her reaction, Dummling boldly requested the princess’s hand in marriage. But the king, unimpressed by the young man’s simplicity, refused. He proposed a challenge: *Bring me a man who can drink an entire cellar of wine.* Dummling, undeterred, ventured into the forest, where he encountered a man with a deep, unquenchable thirst. The man, weary and sorrowful, explained that no amount of drink could satisfy his need. Dummling, seeing an opportunity, invited the man to return with him to the palace, where he believed the king’s challenge could be met.

---

- The specific location where Dummling finds the thirsty man (the place where he had felled the tree) is missing.
- The original dialogue between Dummling and the thirsty man is not present; instead, the completion summarizes their exchange.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Soon afterwards he came to a city, where a king ruled who had a daughter who was so serious that no one could make her laugh. The king had offered a great reward to anyone who could bring a smile to her face, but many had tried and failed. When the young man heard this, he decided to try his luck. He was known for his cleverness and quick wit, so he made his way to the palace. The princess sat in a high tower, her face as pale as the moon, never smiling, never laughing. The young man approached her with a calm smile and said, “Your Majesty, I have come to make you laugh.” The princess looked at him with cold eyes and said nothing. He then pulled out a small mirror and held it up to her. “Look into this mirror,” he said, “and you will see the most beautiful woman in the world.” The princess looked into the mirror and, to her surprise, saw a reflection of herself, but with a mischievous glint in her eye. She couldn’t help it—she laughed. It was a soft, sweet sound that filled the room. The king was overjoyed and immediately offered the reward. The young man, however, asked for the princess’s hand in marriage instead. The king, grateful and pleased, agreed, and the two were married in a grand ceremony. From that day on, the princess was never seen without a smile on her face.

events.title: Completing the Wine Task and Receiving the Bread Task
detailed_summary: Dummling led the thirsty man into the king's cellar.
The man leaned over the enormous barrels and drank continuously until his loins ached.
Before the day ended, he had completely emptied all the barrels.
Dummling then asked for his bride once more.
However, the king was annoyed that such an unprepossessing fellow, known to everyone as Dummling, should marry his daughter, and he imposed a new condition.
This time, Dummling was required to find a man who could consume an entire mountain of bread.

Dummling did not hesitate but went directly into the forest. There, in the same location as before, he found a man who was cinching his body with a strap, making a terrible face, and lamenting that despite eating an entire ovenful of rolls, his great hunger persisted, his stomach remained empty, and he had to bind himself to avoid dying of hunger.

Then Dummling asked once more for his bride, but the king was vexed that such an ugly fellow, whom everyone called Dummling, should take away his daughter, and he made a new condition; he must first find a man who could eat a whole mountain of bread. Dummling did not think long, but went straight into the forest, where in the same place there sat a man who was tying up his body with a strap, and making an awful face, and saying: ‘I have eaten a whole ovenful of rolls, but what good is that when one has such a hunger as I? My stomach remains empty, and I must tie myself up if I am not to die of hunger.’

events.title: The Final Tasks, Marriage, and Happy Ending
characters: Man who can eat a mountain of bread
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the man's plight, Dummling was pleased and told him to get up and accompany him, promising he would eat his fill.
He led the man to the king's palace, where all the flour from the entire kingdom had been gathered.
From this flour, an enormous mountain of bread was baked.
The man from the forest stood before it, began to eat, and by the close of one day, the entire mountain of bread had disappeared.
For the third time, Dummling asked for his bride.
The king, however, sought another way out and ordered Dummling to procure a ship capable of sailing on both land and water.
The king stated that as soon as Dummling returned sailing in such a ship, he would receive his daughter as his wife.
Dummling went straight into the forest, where the little grey man to whom he had given his cake was sitting.
When the little grey man heard what Dummling required, he said that because Dummling had given him food and drink, he would provide the ship, attributing his help to Dummling's past kindness.
He then gave Dummling the ship that could sail on land and water.
When the king saw this vessel, he could no longer prevent Dummling from having his daughter.
The wedding was celebrated, and after the king's death, Dummling inherited his kingdom and lived for a long time contentedly with his wife.

events.text_segment:
At this Dummling was glad, and said: ‘Get up and come with me; you shall eat yourself full.’ He led him to the king’s palace where all the flour in the whole Kingdom was collected, and from it he caused a huge mountain of bread to be baked. The man from the forest stood before it, began to eat, and by the end of one day the whole mountain had vanished. Then Dummling for the third time asked for his bride; but the king again sought a way out, and ordered a ship which could sail on land and on water. ‘As soon as you come sailing back in it,’ said he, ‘you shall have my daughter for wife.’
Dummling went straight into the forest, and there sat the little grey man to whom he had given his cake. When he heard what Dummling wanted, he said: ‘Since you have given me to eat and to drink, I will give you the ship; and I do all this because you once were kind to me.’ Then he gave him the ship which could sail on land and water, and when the king saw that, he could no longer prevent him from having his daughter. The wedding was celebrated, and after the king’s death, Dummling inherited his kingdom and lived for a long time contentedly with his wife.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At this Dummling was glad, and said: ‘Get up and come with me; you shall eat yourself full.’

The old woman did as she was told, and followed Dummling into the forest. He led her a long way, and at last brought her to a little house, where a poor old man was sitting. ‘You are just in time,’ said Dummling; ‘we were just going to eat, and you shall have a share.’

The old man looked at the old woman with suspicion, but Dummling said: ‘Do not be afraid, she is a good old woman, and has given me this beautiful red cap and this little cap for my sister.’

Then they sat down to eat, and the old woman ate and ate until she was quite full. After that, she said: ‘Now I must go home, and I will give you both a present for your kindness.’

With that, she took out a little box and gave it to Dummling, and another to his sister. ‘Open them not until you are at home,’ she said.

Then she went away, and the old man and Dummling went back to their little house. When they were alone, Dummling said: ‘Now let us open the boxes and see what is in them.’

He opened his first, and out jumped a little dog, which began to bark and run about the room. Then his sister opened hers, and out jumped a little cat, which began to purr and rub against her.
